text: The next item is the Commission statement on mitigating the consequences of earthquakes in Croatia (2021/2504(RSP)). Members will be informed that, even at this part-session, the debates will not give the floor on request and the blue card questions will not be accepted. I would also like to point out that the speeches can be spoken remotely from the liaison offices of the Member States.

name: Dubravka Šuica
text: Vice President of the Commission. – Madam President, I'm taking this point on behalf of my colleague, Elisa Ferreira, the Commissioner responsible for cohesion and reforms. Few events have the capacity to shake us to our very core like an earthquake, and for anyone who has experienced it, you know how it feels when your whole world literally starts to crumble around you. Your thoughts go instantly to your loved ones, especially the most vulnerable, who need your help to get safely out of the very building that, up to just a few short ago seconds, provided their sense of security. After the main shock come the aftershocks, which can be equally fatal as the remaining fragments fall. When these terrible moments have passed, attention must turn to rebuilding, because rebuild we must. I'm proud to say that Croatia does not rebuild alone. I was in Croatia when the earthquake hit. In the immediate aftermath, along with my fellow compatriots, I realised that Croatia was not alone. The solidarity shown in response to Croatia's time of need was again outstanding. I take this opportunity to thank this House for its support and each and every Member State that offered immediate assistance in the form of much-needed housing containers, winterised tents, sleeping bags, beds and electrical heaters.  With my colleague Commissioner Janez Lenarčič, I visited Petrinja and Glina with the Croatian Deputy Prime Minister to assess first-hand the immediate assistance needed by the people and local authorities. Of course, lives are the most precious of all, and it saddens me to report that eight people lost their lives and many were injured. On behalf of the European Commission and of our European Union, I take this opportunity to send their families and loved ones our deepest condolences. To those injured and recovering from the effects of the earthquake, we stand beside you. Dear Chairman, the resolution of this Parliament notes concerns about the possible further depopulation of the affected areas as a result of the economic and social consequences of the earthquake.  As vice president for democracy and demography, I share your concern. The resolution rightly draws attention not only to the economic and structural side of the recovery, but also to the psychological effects that such an event can have. National, regional and local authorities need our help and support in this. And this is an opportunity to recall Article 174. the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which states that the Union will always work to strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion in order to promote harmonious development and always seek to reduce differences in the development of individual regions. This article recalls that special attention should be paid to rural areas exposed to negative demographic trends. This needs to be handled when approaching the reconstruction of this region, which means creating conditions for the population to remain in parallel with reconstruction, which is also a major theme of the long-term vision for rural areas to be adopted by the Commission soon.  After this series of earthquakes, let me outline our response and support in three points. First, European support is in imminent danger. Secondly, European support in recovery efforts and the third is the next steps in partnership with the Croatian authorities.  Immediately after the 22 March earthquake in Zagreb, the European Union Civil Protection Mechanism was activated. The Commission has also activated copernicus emergency management services to provide vital information and logistical support to rescue and damage assessment operations on the ground. Support under the European Union Civil Protection Mechanism and the Copernicus Emergency Mapping satellite system was reactivated when several earthquakes struck central Croatia on 29 and 30 December 2020 and 6 January 2021. European Union solidarity was shown immediately and most of the requests were met within 24 hours of the Activation of the Mechanism.  However, crisis support is not enough, so this brings me to my second point, namely European support for recovery and reconstruction efforts. The European Union Solidarity Fund was mobilised last year following the March earthquake in Zagreb. It was this Parliament that approved EUR 683 million in support. This is the second largest absolute amount ever paid out of the Solidarity Fund. It is also by far the largest ever in relative terms, representing 1.26% of Croatia's gross social product. This demonstrates once again the importance of the European Union Solidarity Fund as a single Union instrument, specifically designed for natural disasters. He provided important and timely assistance to Croatia. The Solidarity Fund supports Croatian authorities and locals in the recovery of basic infrastructure, in cleaning operations, in providing temporary accommodation and in the protection of cultural heritage, but we can still do more. And this brings me to the third point, which are the next steps in partnership with the Croatian authorities.  After emergency situations caused by natural disasters, immediate the priority is to assess the damage caused by the earthquake and the Commission is ready to assist the Croatian authorities in doing so. Based on the damage assessment, the European Union Solidarity Fund may be relaunched to respond to Croatia's request for further support for recovery and reconstruction efforts.  More broadly, we need to adopt a comprehensive approach to earthquake reconstruction and recovery, including all activities and assets affected by the quake. Natural disasters always remind us that we need to focus on prevention, adaptation to climate change and risk management. The Commission services are already talking to national authorities. Available resources under Cohesion Policy, the Recovery and Resilience Facility, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development are here to help croatian citizens. This includes investing in catastof risk mitigation measures and climate change adaptation measures, for example as part of a national recovery and resilience plan, a flagship initiative was developed to rebuild the building after the 22 March earthquake in Zagreb last year. The Commission supports those most affected to recover from this damage, to be more resilient in the future and to return Croatia to a path of sustainable growth and a better future. Croatia is not alone because Europe was there every time at the moment of crisis.

name: Karlo Ressler
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Dear Chairman, colleagues and colleagues, the cold Sunday morning at the very beginning of the first lockdown in March will remain deeply etched in the memory of all Zagreb residents. We were awakened by one of the strongest earthquakes in all of Croatian history, which in ten seconds of total power in front of nature, destroyed the homes of thousands of families and severely damaged the socio-cultural core of the Croatian capital.   The harrowing images of nurses and doctors evacuating pregnant women, mothers and newborn babies from the hospital, among them my wife and newborn daughter, will remain deeply etched in our collective memory.  Only as subsequent smaller quakes began to subside and fear slowly subsided, Croatia was unfortunately hit by new earthquakes, this time another devastating earthquake in Sisak-Moslavina County, taking new human casualties and leaving thousands of families without their homes and safety.  Despite the pandemic and shock, Croatian authorities, volunteers, health workers, the Croatian Army and thousands and thousands of citizens have shown the true face of Croatia - communion in the most difficult situations and solidarity towards the most affected.  By providing the most necessary equipment through the Civil Protection Mechanism, other European countries have also shown that Croatia is not alone.  We are grateful to everyone who has been helped. We have a huge job ahead of us and the rebuilding will be time-consuming.  But only together will we help those who have perished, build our homes and rebuild life in the affected regions.

name: Tonino Picula
text: On behalf of the S&D. Club – Dear Chairman, I also thank you for this discussion and the agreed text of the resolution.  This is a clear support of the European Parliament for the citizens of Croatia. I offer my deep condolences to the families of the victims killed in this catastrophic earthquake as well as to support the citizens without homes. Fans of rival teams helped the victims together, top chefs who do not work for them because of the pandemic have cooked for them from day one, donations from citizens from member states are coming, help is on the ground, thank you all. In a catastrophe it is difficult to find anything positive but this wave of solidarity, humanism is an extraordinary dimension of this tragedy.  We owe the victims urgently to ensure adequate housing, transparent spending of aid, building a better system, because this one unfortunately proved in practice that it needs to be reformed. It is of utmost importance that destroyed and damaged structures be restored in accordance with all safety standards, to be seismically resilient and not as in some cases during post-war reconstruction, which must be investigated. It is important that we build basic infrastructure in reconstruction that was not even before the earthquake and that good development policy, stopping emigration, enable the development of this long neglected area.

name: Valter Flego
text: on behalf of the Renew Club. – Dear Chairman, respected colleagues, 2020 was a very difficult year for the whole of Europe, for the whole world, of course because of the fight with COVID-19. But for Croatia it was terrible, it was terrible because besides the fight with Covid, Croatia was hit by two terrible earthquakes. The first 22.3. magnitude 5.5 on Richter hit our capital Zagreb and the second at the end of the year, 29.12. area of central Croatia and Sisak-Moslavina County magnitude 6.4 degrees. Unfortunately, the first quake killed one person, in the second 7. I offer my deepest condolences. That's why this resolution of ours is important. That is why a strong resolution is important that requires all possible long-term assistance, yes, long-term, because reconstruction will take some time, the European Union and the Commission need to find ways from the Solidarity Fund, from the Civil Protection Mechanism but also from the budget 2021-2027. Croatia needs help now and immediately, and therefore needs to reduce bureaucracy and administration and maximise solidarity. Dear colleagues, the earthquake in Croatia is an earthquake in Europe and your help and solidarity, the help and solidarity of every volunteer, every firefighter, every citizen is a light in this disaster, in this tragedy and we will never, ever forget that. And believe me, it's much, much easier when you know you're not alone in trouble. And that's why I call on you to support this resolution and to make one new, major step forward to help affected areas and bring life, the economy back to this area.

name: Roman Haider
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, this House, I would like to thank the President-in-House for the work he has Natural disasters always hit people hard and suddenly. Unfortunately, this is what happened to our Croatian friends at the turn of the year. In the middle of winter, several earthquakes have wreaked havoc and left many people homeless. Rapid help is also urgently needed to help these people cope with the damage. This, of course, requires the solidarity of Croatia's European partners. There is no question in my part that the EU, as an institution, must provide rapid emergency disaster relief to Croatia. In the face of this disaster, we must not abandon our Croatian friends and partners, and we do not. On behalf of all those who have already helped, I would like to mention and thank the initiators of an aid convoy from Wels, the largest city in my constituency in Upper Austria. Led by Mayor Andreas Rabl, aid was brought to Petrinja in Croatia on the night of 12 January. Thank you very much for all such initiatives.

name: Caroline Roose
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, the year 2020 has left a profound impact on Croatia. A first earthquake in March of extreme violence, the COVID crisis, a second earthquake in December. The Croats show great courage, mutual aid and solidarity. Many people mobilized to save lives as temperatures approached zero degrees. This solidarity must continue at European level. We must help them rebuild their homes and communities so that they can live with dignity and security. The European Union has provided EUR 683 million through the Solidarity Fund to help rebuild and help Croatia cope with the devastating effects of the earthquake. In the resolution to be voted on today, we call for a sustainable, resilient and anti-seismic reconstruction and for financial aid to be distributed quickly to enable Croatia to recover quickly. It is not normal that houses rebuilt in the 1990s after the war did not withstand the earthquake better. The Croatian authorities must investigate possible irregularities in the reconstruction. Today we still have important new proof of what the European Union's solidarity really means as a common European project.

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Of course, I would like to begin by expressing my deep sympathy to all those affected by this earthquake in Croatia, to all those who have lost loved ones and to those who have also been affected in material terms.  The situation after the earthquake in Croatia has once again shown international solidarity in crisis situations. Assistance under the EU Civil Protection Mechanism has been mobilised and Poland and Turkey have provided bilateral assistance. In response to a request from the Croatian side, my country, Poland, provided military housing tents for several hundred people and additional necessary equipment, such as beds, mattresses, sleeping bags and bed linen sets. Thanks to the rapid actions, this help went to those in need already on New Year's Day.  This was not the first or last aid that, in the framework of European solidarity, has flowed from Polish to a country affected by tragedy, in this case an earthquake. In 2018, as Minister of The Interior and Administration in the government of Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki, I made the decision at the request of Sweden to refer Polish firefighters to fight the unprecedented scourge of forest fires in the country's history. To this day, I have in my eyes the image of the joint struggle between Polish and Swedish firefighters with fires. This situation, as well as the rapid response of countries to the current situation in Croatia, show what true international solidarity is in the face of tragedy.

name: Younous Omarjee
text: on behalf of the band The Left. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the inclusion of this debate by our Parliament on the agenda on the earthquakes that have struck Croatia is a reminder of what the European Union is: an area of solidarity and an expression of brotherhood that drives us all when one of the peoples of the European Union is faced with the test.  And I want to again this morning to express my condolences to the families and to express my deep solidarity with Croatia, which has had to deal with these earthquakes in an already terribly difficult year in 2020, affected by the COVID-19 pandemic and the crisis it has created. As you said, Commissioner, the European Union Solidarity Fund has been mobilised, but the effort to rebuild infrastructure, economic recovery and social repair is extremely important and I call on the Commission to deploy the necessary funds and aid as quickly as possible.  All European instruments must be combined to support reconstruction. Of course, those of cohesion policy, but also those of recovery. In conclusion, I would like to say that the earthquakes in Croatia also remind us that Europe is, in many places, threatened by earthquakes. This was the case in Italy not so long ago and we know that tomorrow, here or there, a major earthquake could occur. And that is why we will have to put in place real regional strategies to adapt to volcanic and seismic risks.

name: Ivan Vilibor Sinčić (NI).
text: – Dear Chairman, colleagues and colleagues, 2020 has not been an easy year for Croatia.  I would like to take this opportunity to thank all the peoples of Europe and organisations for the assistance they have provided in the earthquake. The earthquake showed the best, but unfortunately the worst of Croatia. Looking at all these volunteers in the first hours of the earthquake, you could easily get the impression that the whole of Croatia had descended there on Banovina or Banija to help, but also much more than Croatia.  Unfortunately, bureaucracy and corruption remain our enemies and even this moment many still do not have a caravan or container to accommodate. In the short term, people must be given everything to have as many normal conditions as possible, but in the long term these areas of Bania but not only Bania but from Syrmia through Bania to Dalmatia, which are devastated and ravaged need not only to be restored, but also to settle. All these areas represent ideal conditions for the development of renewable energy sources, they represent ideal conditions for the development of organic agriculture. Why not make these areas a European core of the development of organic farming. Let a number of research institutes open there to develop these activities.  Let it be a beautiful green Croatian ecological zone and make it as rich as it is beautiful.

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, distinguished colleagues, on 29 December last year Croatia was hit by a magnitude 6.2 earthquake on Richter, which was felt throughout the country as well as in neighbouring countries.  The towns of Petrinja, Sisak and Glina were almost destroyed as well as the surrounding towns and thousands of people lost their homes. Unfortunately, seven lives were lost in the earthquake and this way I offer my condolences to the families of these unfortunate people. The situation is further exacerbated by the fact that the earthquake hit precisely those parts of Croatia that were badly damaged in the Homeland War and which therefore belong to the least developed parts of the country.  However, it is important to point out that the Government of the Republic of Croatia, in this difficult time of the pandemic, reacted quickly and appropriately after the earthquake itself by offering all people who were left homeless alternative accommodation. Today I want to thank the Croatian Army, police, mountain rescue service, firefighters, all medical professionals and volunteers for all the selflessness they have shown in the most difficult moments for Croatia since the Homeland War. Colleagues, at key moments, Croatia remained united in solidarity. I also thank you, our European friends for the support you have shown us and all the countries that have sent assistance for earthquake-stricken areas. I consider it necessary that the European institutions continue to provide further assistance to Croatia, primarily through the Solidarity Fund for earthquake-affected areas as has been done before for Zagreb and through cohesion policy.  This will help rebuild infrastructure in a devastated area but also develop the economy to bring life back to this area, which is what we all want together.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: – Dear Chairman, esteemed colleagues, I would first like to express my deep condolences to the families of the victims and then thank the European Commission and the Member States for their solidarity and assistance to Croatia in these difficult times.  Real friends are the ones you can count on in trouble. Rebuilding is now a priority, it has to help people left homeless. For this purpose, there are a number of opportunities provided by European programmes and mechanisms such as the renovation renovation and structural funds. The Commission also included anti-austerity measures and the modernisation of the housing stock. I call on the Croatian Government to make the most of these opportunities as soon as possible and for the Commission to show flexibility in apogising projects and programmes that will serve the reconstruction of the devastated area.  But in order for life and people to return to Bania, they must have something to live on. That is why, among other things, it is necessary to prioritise activities around reconstruction to local people and businesses, and it must not happen that politically fit and connected profit from it.

name: Thomas Waitz (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Two earthquakes in one year, the last with 6.5 on the Richter scale. The damage is enormous. The challenges facing society are enormous, especially after a year of crisis such as the last. It is good that we in the Union are working together to support our member Croatia, with financial resources and with everything and the solidarity that we can muster. How can it be, however, that the Slovenian-Croatian nuclear power station, just 80 kilometres from the epicentre, cannot be found in this document? Is it not the order of the day to see that a life-threatening, unreasonable project will be found in the second nuclear reactor to be built? Is it not unreasonable to continue to build nuclear power stations in an earthquake region, precisely where these earthquakes have taken place? Even the French Nuclear Safety Agency – and France is probably not a nuclear denier – expresses its grave concerns here. I call on the Croatian Government to reconsider its position here and to refrain from a second bloc in Krsko for the benefit of the populations. This is not what earthquake-proof reconstruction looks like.

name: Traian Băsescu (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to express my solidarity with the families who have suffered from the earthquake in Croatia, with the Croatian people, with the Croatian government. Romania was also among the countries that immediately responded to the Zagreb government's request for help.  I would, however, make an extension of the debate. The European Union has a wide area affected by earthquakes of great magnitude. I mean Romania, Greece, Italy, insular Greece. We will have to learn from these unfortunate effects, and the first lesson is that we have to learn to build better, and the second is that it has become an emergency strengthening of old buildings that are not built according to standards that allow them to withstand earthquakes in areas declared to be high-risk areas and high-risk areas.  We saw large earthquakes in Romania in 1977, when 33 blocks collapsed in Bucharest, when 1,600 people lost their lives, when 3,000 people were injured.  We have an obligation to take measures to prevent the collapse of buildings in the earthquake.

name: Romana Jerković (S&D).
text: – Dear Chairman, the Motto of the European Union "United in Diversity" has never made more sense for us. The incredibly fast action of citizens from Croatia and neighbouring countries has clearly shown us that in global crises we must seek an exit in solidarity and togetherness. Most of the citizens are located and provided with basic living conditions but now comes a much harder part, which is the reconstruction of Bania. This is an opportunity for green energy renovation and a transition that will affect the reduction of energy poverty in the future. The renovation process must be comprehensive, high-quality, with an emphasis on anti-economic, but also sustainable construction. Our priority should be to activate local companies through reconstruction and provide citizens of Petrinja, Glina, Sisak, but also all citizens of Bania with the opportunity to work where they live. Energy-efficient renovation is a unique opportunity to set new standards of transparency. I invite you from this place to transfer knowledge and technology to Bania. Let this earthquake be a new beginning for the areas affected by the earthquakes, but also for the whole of Croatia and let Banija be a positive example of the implementation of the European renovac strategy. Thank you to everyone who selflessly helped us.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, the beautiful country of Croatia was demolished in the last war that took place on European soil. The resistance of our citizens and the willingness to start over have given us the strength to rebuild the country. And then in the middle of the Croatian Presidency of the Council of the European Union there was a pandemic. Unfortunately, that was just the beginning. In March of the same year, a devastating earthquake toppled the historic city of Zagreb. When we thought that this unfortunate year would end with this human tragedy and natural disaster, a horrific earthquake of magnitude 6.4 on Richter hit the Croatian region of Banovina and completely toppled the city of Petrinja. The ground is still tremors, bringing sleepless nights to the citizens of Croatia. I would like to commend the swift reaction of the Croatian Government, which has, among other things, activated the European Civil Protection Mechanism. This improved mechanism on which I worked once again pointed out to Croatian citizens the benefits of membership in the European Union. I will continue to promote another necessary aspect of European instruments, namely the prevention and redesign of new houses that offer protection to the population from possible future disasters. Through the budget of the "NEXT GENERATION EU" and the recently presented initiative "Bauhaus" by Commission President von der Leyen, pilot projects can be established for the safe reconstruction of earthquake-affected areas in Croatia. With this resolution, we call on the Commission to speed up the process and show flexibility in supporting Croatia in this difficult situation.

name: Sunčana Glavak (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, colleagues and colleagues, the earthquakes left sad scenes of destroyed homes missing at the moment and, according to initial estimates, over forty-five thousand structures were damaged in total.  Lives have been lost and I offer my deep condolences to their families. The Government of the Republic of Croatia has made great efforts to normalise the situation on the ground as soon as possible. 120 million kuna of assistance from the state budget for the affected areas was mobilized, a headquarters was established to address the consequences of the earthquake disaster. All actors in the civil protection and homeland security system were on site, did and continued to do an excellent job. I thank everyone, soldiers, police, civil protection, firefighters, Croatian Mountain Rescue Service, representatives of local administration and state institutions and companies, but also a large number of volunteers. Thank you also to our family in the European Union for their selfless assistance, support and solidarity, but also for all the countries that have sent assistance to Croatia and shown the importance of rapid mobilization, the strength of this instrument, but also of communion. And as we talk about physical renovation and home renovation, we must bear in mind economic and demographic revitalization. This is crucial for the future of this area, which is also taken into account by the Government of the Republic of Croatia.  You know that, Madam Vice President, you were there. And finally, I thank you, fellow members, for expressing your sympathy during the difficult days and today in the debate and providing much needed support to all Croatian citizens. We follow that and appreciate it, thank you very much.

name: Dubravka Šuica
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Dear Chairman, thank you very much for your statements. I fully understand the emotionality of coming forward and thank you for everything you've said. Dear MPs, this is what is leading me to say that Croatia is not alone, it is important to repeat it here today. Europe has always been there when there were moments of crisis, providing assistance, from logistics to supporting emergency services. Europe actively supports recovery and reconstruction efforts. Europe understands the necessity of targeted measures to provide a type of assistance to those most in need. The European Union Solidarity Fund is once again showing its value. In relation to the Fund, once again, once the immediate assistance to the population and the response to the December earthquake that followed are under control, the Croatian authorities should assess the damage caused to determine whether it exceeds the relevant thresholds for major regional disasters. This is a basic condition for applying for assistance from the European Solidarity Fund. Croatian authorities have 12 weeks from the date of the disaster to apply for assistance from the Solidarity Fund, and the European Commission is ready to help.  Yes, dear representatives, Mr. Flego, the earthquake took place in Europe. The quake occurred on European soil. All this international solidarity really raises hopes and convinces us even more of the importance of the European project. That's why I once again recalled Article 174. the Treaty establishing the European Union which states that no region must be left behind and this is very important to re-note, and it is the obligation of the European Commission to take this into account.  Once again, we understand the importance and real need for an instrument such as the European Union Solidarity Fund. As part of the proposal for a multiannual financial framework and next generation of the EU, the European Commission has proposed a much larger budget for this instrument. But needs are growing, as you know, and resources are limited. Nevertheless, we will strive to mobilise all possible funds, including financial planning, to ensure an appropriate need for Croatia. We call on the Croatian authorities to assess the damage caused by the earthquake as soon as possible. There are several structural measures, as you have noted, under the Cohesion and Agricultural Development Fund, as well as the Recovery and Resilience Mechanism, which can support reconstruction and recovery as well as strengthen resilience and better preparedness, as you have noted, when it comes to earthquakes and volcanoes and other natural disasters.  Last December, I contacted the Croatian Parliament, the Committee on European Affairs and informed members of our support under the next multiannual financial framework. For the next seven years, Croatia will benefit significantly, as you know, from the financing of the European Union. It is Croatia that will receive cohesion allocation of EUR 8.1 billion, which is one of the largest grants of all 27 Member States, with the amount of EUR 270 per citizen, which amounts to approximately HRK 2 100.00. In addition, Croatia will receive EUR 4.2 billion from the Common Agricultural Policy, which together with the Recovery and Resilience Mechanism accounts for much more than EUR 20 billion.  Europe will be there in the future. The Commission stands ready to assist Croatia in every way on the road to a sustainable and comprehensive recovery. My colleagues Elisa Ferreira, Janez Lenarčič and I will remain in close contact with the Croatian government and will continue to closely monitor the situation on the ground. And in line, once again, in line with the motto of cohesion policy and the Solidarity Fund, no region shall be left behind, no citizen of the European Union shall be forgotten.

Again, I would like to inform you that, during this part-session, the debates will not give the floor on request and the blue card questions will not be accepted. I would also like to point out that the speeches can again be used remotely from the liaison offices of the Member States.

name: Frances Fitzgerald
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, nobody left untouched: that’s the terrifying reality of this virus. Nobody left untouched, but no equality in how this terrifying disease hits individuals, families, communities, nations or genders. The silent funerals with a sad scattering of masked mourners testify that more men than women are dying from the virus. This gender differential increases with age. Older men, sadly, are dying from the virus in greater numbers than older women. We must examine and learn why and do what we can to keep each other safe. I suggest that each one of you has felt, perhaps this very minute, that your life has been put on pause, halted, stilled, silenced. The tragedy is that in each of our nations, to a greater or lesser extent, health care has been put on pause, halted, so cancer treatment and access to sexual and reproductive health services have declined. Never again. We must regard this as the opportunity to act like never before in the field of health and build a functioning health union. It’s time to get to work, and I have to say that President von der Leyen has made an excellent start. As we consider those who receive health care, let’s consider those who deliver it, the ones who got sporadic applause as they got us through this crisis: the 76% of health-care workers who are women, the 93% of childcare workers who are women, the 95% of domestic cleaners who are women, and the 86% of personal care workers who are women. Sporadic applause for them? No, not nearly good enough. Commissioner, we are asking you to bring forward pay transparency text urgently. No more gender pay gap for the heroes of this COVID story. But for women workers everywhere, we must do better. We must learn from the last crisis and ensure that Next Generation EU takes account of gender bias. Building and construction are important to turn an economy around in a swift way, but it leaves women behind because men generally do the constructing. Commissioner and Minister, you must put women at the front. As the Commission examines the national action plans for Next Generation EU, we must make sure they are inclusive of women because, when women lose paid employment, they lose just one of their jobs. They go home and go back to the second job and the third job, caring. We know the stories over the past few months: women struggling to find time to sleep in between working, caring for family, home schooling and housework. We must be crystal clear: working from home is not a substitute for childcare. Implementation of a work-life balance will be required to change this. But I believe that the EU can do more: harnessing EU funds for care infrastructure, collecting data on the situation of carers across the EU, and sharing best practice. Surely, Commissioner, it is time for a new European care strategy, and we ask you to bring forward a proposal. Let’s not kid ourselves that work, home schooling, pastimes and housework are all that goes on behind closed doors in lockdown. The truth is that children and women are particularly often imprisoned with the violent in their own homes.  Member States must pivot services to help and support them, ensuring that law enforcement and courts have their backs, but also that civil society can provide the essential services of phone lines and shelters. It can’t wait, this shadow pandemic, it cannot be put on hold. The EU must combat violence against women, ratifying the Istanbul Convention, adding violence against women to the list of Euro-crimes, and putting in place a strong legal framework to tackle all forms of gender-based violence. Women are dying and we must intervene. If Europe is to be a leader in the quest for human rights and equality, we must work with our global partners to support and empower women around the world. We must make Team Europe a shining light for women and girls across the world, a byword for a brighter post—COVID future. Colleagues, now we must look to the future. COVID has taken so much from us, our daily routines, our moments of joy and so many, heartbreakingly, family, friends, neighbours. Yet we will re-emerge, helped by vaccines. We shouldn’t be aiming at normal; we should be aiming at so much better than normal: a greener future, a more digital future, a gender—equal future. That means reaching out and bringing women to the table. It’s been said that women’s rights are human rights. Similarly, women’s contributions are human contributions, lifting all people to a place where they can see a better future.  One final point. This is a comprehensive and detailed report and I ask colleagues to give it wide support across this Parliament today, but a report is just words on paper without a concrete commitment to implementation. So I have two questions. First, Commissioner Dalli, will you pledge to read the report and reflect on the calls to the Commission? Can you pledge to consider follow—up action based on the recommendations? To the Council, Minister, can you pledge to circulate this report for consideration by Ministers as part of your priority topic on gender equality? Can you pledge to hold a discussion amongst Ministers on it? To both the Council and the Commission, I think your promise today to build back better on gender equality will be key post—COVID because, as we know, we are united in diversity.

name: Puhemies. –
text: Thank you very much to the rapporteur, Frances Fitzgerald, for this speech. I wonder why the Council is not here, because in reality this debate specifically concerns not only the Commission, but also the Council. The rapporteur is quite right that these matters should at least be forwarded to the Council through the Commission.

name: Maria Noichl
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Two good news today for society and especially for women, two good news today: Donald Trump will no longer govern the White House in the future, and the EU will get a new strategy for gender equality this week. I think it's a good day. What is such a strategy for gender equality? First of all, I believe that it must be said that it is once again a kind of location determination for Parliament, for all of us – a determination of the location. Today, the majority of Democrats here in the House are once again positioning themselves unequivocally and unequivocally. It positions itself for an equal society between the sexes. The majority in this House is clearly and unequivocally in favour of a 'no' to violence against women and girls. And it positions itself unequivocally and unequivocally on the obligation to divide participation between the sexes. It positions itself for wage fairness, equal pay and, of course, that women and men are equal in value. And we in Parliament, we in the majority of democrats and democrats here in the House, we are clearly in favour of peace between the sexes. This is also an important point that we must stress again and again: the first peace begins between the sexes. And we position ourselves for a humanistic image of man. The equality strategy is a commitment by this House, a commitment that equality is a value that we are fighting for, but also a commitment that equality is far from being achieved. As the EU, we have an obligation to be the driving force for equality. I would like to make it quite clear once again that violations of the rule of law can also be seen in the violations of women's rights. Anyone who violates women's rights, those who hinder equality, also prevents the rule of law and democracy. I believe that this must be stressed again and again these days. In addition to this positioning, however, the strategy for equality is also a very clear demarcation from what we do not want, namely: we clearly and unambiguously distinguish ourselves here from the very, quite right-wing and the eternal. No, the majority of us in the European Parliament do not support women being reduced to the role of mother only. No, the majority of us in the European Parliament do not support the fact that the man is automatically the head of the family and that family can only be where mum, dad, child is, but there are also colourful families, other family models. The majority of us in the European Parliament are in favour of gender not being a word that can be banned, or an idea that can be banned simply because it cannot be dealt with. We stand for ideas to develop strength that cannot be opposed. I think of an old lyrics from a Bavarian women's group. They sing: "Only those who are very, very small, we wanted to tell you, only they cannot bear the growth of women." That is what I wanted to say to the very, far right here in Parliament. The gender equality strategy is a mandate for the next five years. It is a work plan, a binding work plan, it is a development plan. They are specific tasks: it is a question of a control mechanism and, above all, of reporting obligations. But what exactly is the content now? We fight for goals. The content of the equality strategy, these are measures, but that is what the objectives are. Clearly Objective 1: zero tolerance against violence against women. It is important that the ratification of the Istanbul Convention is finally being pushed forward. And it is also important and right – and once again thank you very much to Mrs Dalli – that, if there is no progress, there is a Plan B. It is important that additional measures are specifically taken against violence against women and, of course, genital mutilation. Women's rights in the area of sexual and reproductive rights, health and fundamental rights must be enshrined in all Member States, and it is important to keep pushing ahead with the collection of data on violence against women. One goal: zero tolerance to violence. The second objective: to focus on diversity, LGBTI groups, intersectionality and so on and so forth. The third objective is wage fairness between men and women, but also wage fairness between sectors. The next goal: participation in the leadership. Here we would like the Portuguese Presidency to do what Germany has failed to do. in fact, to finally press ahead with the women-on-boards directive and make it a reality in Europe and, of course, to fight for parity in parliaments. We have one objective: we aim to ensure that crises are managed jointly, that crises are not dumped on the shoulders of women – and this was already about the financial crisis – and this objective is at the heart of it. We have the objective of tax justice. Tax justice: I mean, it's about gender budgeting. Taxpayers' money belongs to us jointly, to men and women, not just men alone. In addition, we have the goal in the future that there should always be a demand for regular formal meetings of the ministers for equality. Finally, I would like to thank all those who have worked. I would like to thank the democrats in this House who know that there can be no democracy, no rule of law, no development without equality.  Thank you for this good cooperation. I would also like to thank Commissioner Helena Dalli. Finally, I would like to make it quite clear once again that Europe is a woman!

name: Maria da Graça Carvalho
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am very pleased to present this report which addresses one of the most important means of gender discrimination of our day: the huge gap in women's participation in the digital economy. This is a question of social justice for women. Inequality in digital increases the pay gap, with negative consequences also on reforms, and one of today's major problems is the low incomes of retired women. On the other hand, the competitiveness of the European economy is at stake, the main barrier of which is the lack of professionals in new technologies, in particular in digital technologies. A huge bag of talent, creativity, competence and innovation capacity is being wasted. Only 18% of information and communication technology professionals in Europe are women and, if nothing is done, the situation will only tend to get worse as the percentages of students in this area are even more fragile. In fact, among the approximately 1.3 million people studying in ict, only seventeen percent are girls. The report analyzes the data, identifies the potential causes for the current situation and points to solutions, in the form of recommendations, to the Commission, the Member States and society at large. As far as causes are concerned, there are two major phenomena that contribute to this reality.  On the one hand, for the most diverse cultural reasons, girls tend to avoid this area by not considering it a viable career path. On the other hand, many of those who effectively follow this path end up giving up along the way, both as students and as professionals, in a phenomenon that is already dubbed the leaky pipeline effect. There's a lot of work to be done. Thus, we propose a set of actions. Firstly, by calling on The Member States to create entrepreneurship and financing programmes for projects in the ICT sectors aimed at women and, and very importantly, that gender diversity be taken into account in the evaluation for the financing of actions supported by the multiannual financial framework and the European Recovery Plan. Secondly, by encouraging companies and other ICT institutions to create conditions to improve the career progression of their professionals. In education, from the first levels of education, it is necessary to sensitize girls to the importance of these areas, define content that is more appealing to them and presenting success stories of women who have avenged and can serve as a reference in this professional area. We also propose measures in terms of culture, media and audiovisuals. Some of these means unconsciously contribute to the eternization of certain stereotypes. It is important that they are encouraged to change the way they portray women's relationship with technologies, both in information and fiction. Tackling this digital divide is not an exclusive task for public institutions and bodies. It is up to all, all stakeholders, whether they hold public, private, academy positions, to carry out specific actions to strengthen women's participation and role in the digital economy. A final word to thank my colleagues, all the political groups without exception, who, with their numerous contributions and commitment, have enabled us to achieve a cohesive and humanist final text. We will have a single vote, no amendments or any request for a split vote.

name: Eugenia Rodríguez Palop
text: drafts member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Madam President, I will highlight some of the points which I consider right in the report which has been drawn up on the strategy for equality in a context of a health crisis. In this strategy we are committed to incorporating a European care pact to increase public services and improve the conditions of those who work there, overcoming the precariousness and social undervaluation to which these people are subjected. We also say that telework cannot serve as an excuse to continue dismantling and privatize kindergartens or nursing homes, and that reconciliation is decisive if we do not want to overburden women and collapse as a society, and if we do not want to increase the feminization of poverty. We want no postponement of measures that seek to reduce the gender gap. What does the Commission expect to present the proposal for a Wage Directive? And the companies, where are they, when are they going to take responsibility? We want companies that fail to fail to be sanctioned and that financial support be provided for compliance with labour regulations and the absence of discriminatory practices. But we also want the Commission to monitor cases where the protection of women's rights has been regressed, that there should be an alarm system and that the links between far-right anti-democratic movements and disinformation campaigns on women's rights and the Istanbul Convention be analysed. Finally, as a powerful gentleman, we have insisted that the gender perspective be incorporated into funds and recovery plans and the European budget. If the axes of future investment are, as it seems, the digital and ecological transition, we have to be there and we cannot be left behind.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank the European Parliament for putting gender equality on the agenda today. I also obviously extend my thanks to the rapporteurs and the shadows who have worked on finalising the three reports we are discussing today. Every day we continue to discover more about the havoc which the COVID—19 pandemic has played, and is playing, on the lives of people who are already in disadvantaged positions in our societies, and about how existing inequalities have been exacerbated. Many women, as frontline workers, were at the deep end of this pandemic and thus impacted by it disproportionately. But this is not only at the place of work. While at home, confinement measures have kept many women in abusive and hostile environments. The situation of closed schools and childcare facilities meant more care work for many women. Many lost their jobs and thus their financial independence.  All this means that we must, more than ever before, step up our work towards equality. It is with this conviction in mind that the Commission continues to work with one goal in mind: to do everything in our power not to leave anyone behind. This Commission has already taken a number of actions in response to the social and economic consequences of the pandemic. In particular, the EU long—term budget 2021—2027, together with Next Generation EU, form the largest stimulus package ever financed, through the EU budget, of EUR 1.8 trillion. This will promote gender equality through gender mainstreaming and specific targeted measures.  In line with its commitment to the Gender Equality Strategy and the Interinstitutional Agreement, the Commission is working on the development of a methodology to track gender—related expenditure at programme level and in the new MFF. This will bring significant progress on gender mainstreaming across all EU policies.  Gender mainstreaming is also at the core of the Gender Equality Strategy, which I presented in March last year. The crisis we are living today has only amplified the importance of this strategy. It has confirmed the need to address core issues such as women’s economic empowerment, violence against women and the gender digital gap, which are all priorities of the Gender Equality Strategy.  The first major initiative of the strategy is the proposal to introduce binding pay transparency measures. We are in the final preparation phase and aim to present the proposal shortly. In essence, the purpose is to detect and prevent gender—based pay discrimination or unjustified pay differences and empower those being discriminated against to enforce the right to equal pay.  The Commission will move forward also with new initiatives on gender equality. By the end of 2021, we will present a legislative proposal to prevent and combat specific forms of gender—based violence. This year we are preparing an initiative to extend the list of EU crimes to include hate speech and hate crime, including on the basis of a person’s gender. These actions will be followed by a recommendation on the prevention of harmful practices against women and girls, such as female genital mutilation, to address the need for effective pre—emptive measures, acknowledge the importance of education and strengthen public services. Based on work already started, we will establish a cooperation framework with internet platforms to tackle online violence against women and girls. We are preparing initiatives in the area of childcare and long—term care. We will propose the revision of the Barcelona targets on childcare and propose a child guarantee on social inclusion of children from disadvantaged backgrounds, including through affordable and quality early childhood education and care.  We will also adopt a comprehensive strategy on the Rights of the Child, which seeks to ensure equal rights, protection and support to all children regardless of background, origin, gender or residence status. We will publish a report on long—term care, which will also be adopted this year. The report will also analyse the gender dimension of long—term care, including the impact of the provision of informal care.  It is essential that we follow up and keep monitoring the development and implementation of the strategy. International Women’s Day would be a good opportunity to take stock of what has been implemented one year from the adoption of the strategy.  The need to address the digital gender gap is absolute. Empowering women’s success in the digital economy opens the doors to growth. The under—representation of women in the digital industries persists, as we have heard. Women are still not involved as much as they should be in our building of a digital future. This is a huge loss of untapped talent to our economies and societies. More women in digital jobs could create an annual EUR 16 billion GDP boost in the EU. For that, we need to encourage girls to study science and technology so that more women choose a career in science, technology, engineering and mathematics, essential areas for developing our digital sphere.  The Commission has taken various steps to encourage more girls and women in the digital sector by supporting networks and challenging gender stereotypes. These culminated in the ministerial declaration of commitment on Women in Digital, where Member States have now agreed to a number of actions to address the various facets of this problem. The Commission will support these efforts under the new MFF and Next Generation EU.  Our efforts to build a more sustainable economy and society through digital innovation depends to a large extent on women’s involvement. Many women’s talents and skills remain untapped. This is a waste of human capital. More women get involved if we start at the root. We must break down stereotypes and bias and encourage girls to choose their parts without influencing them with our biases. We must also give the necessary space for women to thrive in the digital economy and support more women as entrepreneurs and leaders.  I strongly believe that this is key to the transition to a resilient and competitive economy, so I look forward now to hearing your remarks and, of course, I remain available to reply to your questions. Thank you again, thank you for being here, thank you for your report, and thank you for participating in this debate. (Applause)

name: Puhemies. –
text: I shall open today's first votes. We will vote on the procedures announced on today's agenda and the votes will be open from 9.45 a.m. to 11 a.m. The voting method is the same as in previous votes, and all votes are taken by roll call. I hereby declare the first votes open. You can vote until 11:00. The results of the first votes will be announced at 1 p.m.

name: Puhemies. –
text: We will now continue the joint debate – the report by Frances Fitzgerald, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, on the Covid-19 crisis and the period after that, on the gender perspective (2020/2121(INI)) – (A9-0229/2020), – Maria Noichlin's report on the EU strategy on gender equality on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality (2020/2020) (A9-0234/2020) and – Maria da Graça Carvalho's report on the closing of the digital gender gap by Maria da Graça Carvalho on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality: Women's participation in the digital economy (2019/2168(INI)) – (A9-0232/2020).

name: Evin Incir
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Madam President, the gender equality strategy is a product of a struggle of generations of women before us, in Europe and beyond, whose shoulders we are standing on today. I want to thank Commissioner Dalli for the inclusion of intersectional perspective and clearly underlining that discrimination and inequalities are structural and institutionalised. This is the key to break the glass ceiling for all women. This is key to make a true feminist Europe possible. We, therefore, need to support women’s rights defenders and women’s rights organisations in the EU and globally, including organisations working on SRHR, LGBTQI rights and anti-racism, not only financially but also institutionally. It is said that the crisis magnifies already existing problems in societies and so has the current pandemic. The growing violence and exploitation of women and children are two of them. There are, therefore, some proposals and issues the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) and I would like to propose: the importance of an EU anti—trafficking coordinator that can closely monitor the implementation of the anti—trafficking Directive by the Member States and act if they don’t implement it; to support Member States in training law enforcement and judicial staff on gender—based violence and hate crimes, including those committed online. Victims’ rights must be placed in the centre. When we are seeking justice we must do everything we can to prevent discrimination, traumatisation and re—victimisation.

name: Cindy Franssen
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, 26 years after the Fourth World Conference on Women, we are setting out our guidelines on gender equality for the coming years. Because there is still a lot of work to be done in Europe. The numbers don't lie. In this rapidly evolving world, however, it is important to keep women on board. Women's talents are still an underused source of expertise and creativity. That is why we need to close the pay gap through wage transparency. That is why we need to promote female entrepreneurship, further tackle violence against women and break gender stereotypes. That is why we must implement the directive on work-life balance. All these things must be high on the political agenda. To achieve this, we need women at the decision table. The directive on women on boards has been in the freezer long enough. We are already à point for it. While we smashed yet another glass ceiling yesterday with Kamala Harris as the first female vice president, I also want to be crystal clear about our damning duty to take political action for women in vulnerable positions, women in poverty, women with disabilities and women as victims of war violence. It's time for action. The 21st century is up to women.

name: Heléne Fritzon
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner Dalli, I would like to thank you for your support. Yes, shortly after the pandemic was a fact a year ago, civil society, the UN and women's rights campaigners around the world warned that this pandemic is in danger of becoming a gender crisis. But the warnings haven't helped. Women's shelters are still reporting an increase in violence against women. We see devastating consequences for sexual and reproductive health and sexual and reproductive rights. Experience with previous crises suggests that women's economic situation will be affected in the long term. And when women are affected, then our children are also affected. That is why I call on the EU and the Member States to take gender issues very seriously. From the start of the pandemic, I have called for women's rights to be respected and for all measures to be integrated into gender equality, not least in the Budget and Recovery Fund. It is positive and absolutely essential that the EU now has a gender equality strategy. But it is not enough for us to talk about the strategy. We must now ensure that it is followed up and implemented with clear objectives and concrete measures in all policy areas. If we want to repair the economic and social damage of this crisis, it is important to increase women's participation in the labour market – women's right to their own work, their own livelihood. We will also link gender equality work to climate policy and the digital agenda. Now, once and for all, we're going to take this seriously. We will work for an equal Europe because it benefits everyone. I would like to conclude by thanking our rapporteur, Mr Fitzgerald, for his good cooperation. Thanks!

name: Samira Rafaela
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, thank you Commissioner, we can already conclude that the pandemic affects women disproportionately in all ways of life, and women are on the front line of the COVID-19 pandemic and account for 76% of health-care workers across the EU. Women are responsible for most of the informal and unpaid care as well as educational support at home, and women are prone to fall victim to the rising prevalence of domestic violence which has aggravated the already high pre-COVID numbers. Women are also experiencing difficulties in accessing safe sexual and reproductive health services, as abortion was deemed non—essential, forcing women and girls to seek unsafe abortion elsewhere. And as we find ourselves on the verge of recovering from this crisis, the time has come to decide how we as the European Parliament want to shape post-covid Europe. Do we want women to be equally represented in leadership and decision-making and allow women to be part of the design and implementation of recovery plans? Do we take a gender-sensitive approach in our response to the crisis in order to preserve and protect women’s rights? And do we combat domestic violence against women and implement the EU protocols in our emergency response plans? My answer to these questions is yes. Because women’s rights are human rights and this pandemic provides an opportunity to make the real progress women and girls deserve, and I count on all of you to help shaping a post-COVID Europe that is really gender equal. (Applause)

name: Annika Bruna
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Madam President, your strategy for gender equality is more akin to a desire for indifferentiation than a desire for legitimate equity between the sexes. For you, any difference between men and women would be stereotypes that need to be corrected. Your ideology even becomes authoritarian. Nations or NGOs that do not share your goals or theories of gender or intersectionality are denounced. You even intend to impose quotas. A policy that is contrary to the values of equality and meritocracy and undermines the legitimacy of those it purports to promote. Faced with your vision, the ID group proposes an alternative text. We renew our commitment to equality between men and women, their differences and their complementarity. We recall what the European Union's priorities for women's rights should be: the fight against domestic violence, harassment but also the delinquency they suffer, the fight against the various trafficking of human beings of which they are the first victims and which the European policy of borders promotes, the obtaining everywhere of equal pay for equal work and equal skills. Finally, European demographics are at a dramatically low level. Member States should encourage birth rates by, among other things, monetaryly increasing the time spent by mothers who choose it to educate their children. We don't want to force our daughters to become men like any other. Our aim is to guarantee the security of women in Europe, but also the freedom to choose their way of life according to their aspirations, sometimes different from those of men, but always legitimate.

name: Diana Riba i Giner
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to stress the constructive attitude that has taken place during the preparation of this report.  The result is an ambitious text that demonstrates how COVID-19 has only widened gender inequalities that were already unacceptable before the pandemic. This report makes a good analysis of the consequences of COVID from a gender perspective and also makes concrete proposals to reverse, or at least curb, these inequalities. Still, we have to regret two aspects. The first is that the report is late. This text had to be used to influence recovery funds, but its vote comes when packages and measures are already agreed. The second, that we have missed an opportunity to demand an healthcare pact, a care pact that not only invests in the care sector, but also fosters a transition to a care economy that puts the well-being and life of people at the center of all policies. I am sure that we will have the opportunity to discuss the welfare pact, because from now on it must be the central issue for the Union.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Our common goal should be to care for the well-being of women, to ensure that women have the same opportunities and opportunities no matter where they live, the same opportunities and opportunities as men. Our common concern, here in the European Union, should be respect for the Treaties and the competences of the Member States. Our common concern should be respect for the fundamental right, which is the right to life, from which all other rights derive.  Unfortunately, the report has been watered down by left-wing ideology and is actually spoiling everything. In fact, it has become an asumpt for the left to present a kind of political manifesto. Yet, beyond political divisions, we should focus on bridging the pay gap, the pension gap, reducing and best exterminate violence against women: sexual violence, cyberbullying, psychological violence. We have so much to do together. It is here in the European Union that there have been 500 000 cases of female genital mutilation. It is here in the European Union that underage girls are married to adult men. It's time to stop it. It is here in the European Union that women's rights are violated. Let us take care of women's real rights. And the answer to these rights is the resolution of the European Conservatives and Reformists, which responds to all these challenges. I ask you to support it.

name: Silvia Modig
text: On behalf of The Left Group. – Mr President, digitalisation is a big opportunity for us, but only if we do it in such a way that everyone can get involved. Gender equality requires girls and women to have equal access to technology, to train in digital sectors and to be safe online. The pandemic has accelerated the digital transition, and teleworking brought new digital tools to many people's everyday lives. The development is therefore rapid and it is estimated that more than 90% of the jobs of the future will require IT skills and digital literacy. All over the world, women use the Internet less often than men. In order to achieve fully equal opportunities for girls and women to participate in the digital economy, we need to get rid of gender stereotypes and gendered attitudes and expectations. Gender stereotypes have a big impact on young people's study choices, and we need to get girls to see that digital sectors are equally for them too. Unfortunately, the Equality Index 2019 reveals that gender inequality is still widespread in the digital sector. Care responsibilities continue to be unevenly distributed and exacerbated by the pandemic. Women bear most of the responsibility for care, and this is an obstacle to the equal position of women in the labour market and in the world of work. The economic situation also affects the access of all children and young people to digital development. Schools should be places to ensure that, regardless of family background or financial situation, every child has the opportunity to learn digital skills.

name: Dorien Rookmaker (NI).
text: – Madam President, if I am to believe the reports on women’s issues we discuss today, the position of women is getting worse by the minute. There seems to be gender gaps everywhere caused by discrimination, digitalisation, COVID or otherwise. We are seeing more problems than we can solve and that is why we’ll vote against all reports.  The larger the scope, the less chance of positive results. We have to choose our battles to win the war. Let’s concentrate on the important issues: discrimination of women on the labour market, the housing market, the health service, education and above all, discrimination by Member State governments. Let’s focus on these five important battlegrounds and stop searching for new topics and new gender gaps. In der Beschränkung zeigt sich der Meister. Focus on what is really important and bring the gap to a close.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The COVID pandemic has shown the enormity of the tragedy of women who are locked up in their homes so often experiencing physical, mental, economic or sexual violence. She also showed that despite all the inequalities, women were on the front lines in the fight against the virus.  I do not understand, ladies and gentlemen, why in Europe so many politicians would like to ignore issues relating to inequality and violence? Why are so many trying to convince us that these are secondary and surrogate topics? Closes our eyes not to see that people of different sexual orientation live among us? Why do so many think that if we remove the word gender from all legislative documents of the European Union, we will win the fight against some imaginary, dangerous ideology? However, equality, ladies and gentlemen, is not an ideology. Silently, we give permission for violence, exploitation, hejt, sexism and discrimination, which seems to be more and more in the modern world.  I would like to live, ladies and women, in an ideal world where women hold leadership positions as easily as men, including in sectors dominated by men today, such as the iterating, technological, mechanical sector, and not just become victims of cyberbullying, where there is no pay gap and a digital divide where violence is not justified by culture, customs, religion, tradition or honour, in a world where it is on the side of victims and not the perpetrators. I hope that this debate and our action will help all this and change what women across Europe are waiting for.

name: Maria-Manuel Leitão-Marques (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I once heard the story of a computer teacher who was proud that all his pupils participated in the construction of a robot, adding: the boys programmed and the girls sewed the robot's dresses. I think it is a good example to illustrate how stereotypes about women's participation in the digital economy are reproduced from an early age. Under-representation in this important sector of the present and the future is well mirrored in the numbers. Only 17% of the 1.3 million people studying information technology are women. The gender pay gap is larger in this area, 19% against 16% and it is also in ict that there is the highest percentage of male-only boards. Thus, our first fight has to be at school and then in lifelong learning, as we advocate in this report on the digital divide between men and women, namely by creating, at all levels of education, mentoring mechanisms that provide for female reference models in the field of ICT, showing their social impact on the quality of people's lives or by developing training programmes for upskilling and reskilling specifically aimed at women , in order to accelerate its active inclusion in the digital world. Commissioner, let us hope that this report will inspire you to promote equal participation of women in the digital economy with quantifiable and controllable objectives. I would like us to know here a year from now on what the Commission has done and with what results. Once and for all, it was good that robots were dressed by boys and girls and programmed as well.

name: Karen Melchior (Renew).
text: – Madam President, my sister has two children. One is quiet, careful and thinks a lot about what is going on. One is full of energy, cannot sit still, jumps first, thinks later. Our bodies have a gender. Our minds, personality and interests do not. My two nieces are very different — but both girls. I often wonder how much of their personality would have been attributed to their gender if one of them was a boy, when really it is just because they are the persons who they are.  We can dress according to the role we want society to see us in, but all too often society imposes expectations on us, just because of the body we were born into. Ada Lovelace was the first coder in history. She was a woman. She and countless women after her created the digital technologies we’re using today. Yet in the digital sector today, we see gender stereotypes and discrimination hinder access for women. These barriers are cultural in our society and it is essential that we tear these barriers down.  We need to show young girls and women they can be, and they can do, anything they want. We need companies to make sure that they do not push women out. We need a digital transition, a digital economy which provides equal opportunity which empowers everyone regardless of their gender.

name: Nicolaus Fest (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We already had gender in this House last year and the war in Syria. We had gender and climate. We had, of course, gender and digitalization. Now we have gender and COVID. I am frankly surprised that the intellectual flyer here in the room, Mrs Noichl, has not yet come up with the idea of putting gender and the earthquake in Croatia on the agenda as well. However, we in this House have never had the issue of gender and scientific research, or even gender and common sense. Gender is an ideological fake, as gender and COVID is an ideological fake. We have heard it from Mrs Fitzgerald: men are the most affected, because they die most from COVID. And so this whole debate is nonsense. We are all in favour of equality. We are not in favour of equality beyond quality standards, of differentiation, and therefore equality is nothing more than discrimination against men. And we are against it. We are in favour of equality, but against equality. Mrs Dalli, I know, of course, that there are special rights for women and that you are pursuing them above all. But if you have five minutes of language time, I would be grateful if you limit yourself to five minutes and do not overdo it twice, especially since you have little to contribute to this debate in terms of content anyway.

name: Puhemies. –
text: Well, that is the speech by Mr Nicolaus Fest, and then I give the floor to Mrs Kuhnke, please.

name: Alice Kuhnke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the Commission’s gender equality strategy comes at a time when we are witnessing a backlash against our common European values. The pandemic, as we all know, has made things worse and has deepened existing inequalities, in particular for those most marginalised in society. Member States, such as Poland and Hungary, have used the pandemic as an opportunity to introduce new measures to limit access to sexual and reproductive health care, to attack transgender and intersex people’s rights and to roll back on important work to combat gender-based violence. The report we are voting on today sends a strong signal to the Commission and to the regressive Member States of our union. We need to go beyond nice words to deliver real change.

name: Andżelika Anna Możdżanowska (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Thank you for taking up this important subject during the Session of the European Parliament. Closing the digital gap and women's participation in the digital economy is an extremely topical topic at a time of economic competitiveness challenges. But not only that, because especially today it is a huge challenge to fight the economic crisis caused by the coronavirus pandemic. It is today that this economic crisis and the long-term struggle against it is hitting the sectors in which women make up a large part of the labour force. It has been for years that digitalisation has fundamentally changed most aspects of our lives. We already know today that the COVID-19 crisis and its consequences will make lasting changes in life throughout Europe, in the lives of all Europeans, increasing the particular need for digital competences in every area of social and professional life. Not only gender stereotypes are a serious obstacle, but also solutions and opportunities to reconcile work and family life. Because we cannot afford to widen the digital sector, to prevent women from participating. We must seize the full opportunity of women's role as users, innovators, creators, participation in life, the challenges of the economy, especially the digital one. Unfortunately, even today, in the 21st century, women show less confidence in their own digital skills, and it is they who give them the opportunity for equal and fair access, which today, more than ever, in the months of lockdown, we are convinced every day, in our families and in the workplace. And there can be no consent to digital exclusion. They are already frightened by the available data that most workers need to acquire digital skills to maintain their jobs. Worldwide, 75 million jobs could disappear as a result of automation. Thank you very much for taking up this topic and I ask you (inable words) to provide additional resources for accessing and enhancing digital competences.

name: Sandra Pereira (The Left).
text: – Madam President, any strategy for equality must be based on employment policies that eliminate discrimination in access to work and reinforce employment with rights, collective bargaining, the prohibition of precariousness. It requires the enhancement of working conditions, in particular through regulation and reduction of working hours and the requirement for a general increase in wages and pensions and living conditions.
