It must be translated into measures that eradicate poverty and social exclusion and combat its causes, into measures to defend and promote universal and quality public services, such as housing and justice, free access to education and health, including access to sexual and reproductive rights, in measures to protect motherhood , extending the periods of leave and ensuring their payment to 100%, and protection in the disease by consecrating, effecting or expanding rights by law.  It must ensure public investment in the expansion of a network of public facilities at all levels of care, from day care centers and kindergartens to care networks that meet the needs of the most dependent. It must promote, among the States, the guarantee of the implementation of mechanisms and instruments to combat all types of violence, whether in the family context, in the context of work or in other contexts, measures that European Union policies have contradicted, or even prevented, but which we will continue to demand. Finally, we cannot but regret that a strategy for equality refers to prostitution as sex work and not as violence and exploitation.

name: Vladimír Bilčík (PPE).
text: – Madam President. The subject of gender equality is not a political pendant. It affects all of us, women and men equally. I myself wish that men should speak as naturally, passionately and passionately as women about the position of women in society. We also have much to improve on this point in the European Parliament. We often discuss the need to strengthen gender equality in relation to the gender pay gap. Yes, there must be a principle in every profession that everyone deserves the same slice for equal work. And it doesn't matter where he works in Europe and whether a woman or a man does the job. However, if we look more closely at the space of Central Europe, a similarly acute and, moreover, vitally existential problem than salaries is linked to gender inequality. Did you know that two thirds of the people over the age of 65 who materially sedue and have trouble leading a dignified life in Slovakia are women? Yes, it is. It is important that we fight as loudly for gender equality in the labour market as we do about the long-term risk that more women than men are ending their old age in extreme poverty in Europe. The current pandemic will only exacerbate the problem of gender inequality. To anyone who is willing to perceive reality, the pandemic shows how much we depend on women's work, not only in hard-pressed healthcare systems, but also at home. We have known for years how to improve women's social status. Schools, kindergartens or simply take seriously all the nice words we tend to say about women when we have women's anniversaries and memorial days. That's when we're full of admiration. So let's translate that admiration into concrete policies. Recovery after the pandemic gives us a good opportunity.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I wish you all a happy and healthy 2021. A lot of work is ahead of us, above all, the gender pay and the gender pension gap. These gaps are ranging from 3% to 23% and from 1% to a crazy 43% in the European Union. So there’s a lot to do. And in addition, both pay and pension gaps are intrinsically linked to the care gap, mostly women doing all this unpaid care work. What do we do about these gaps? We build bridges. And those bridges should look like binding measures like pay transparency, where we are eagerly waiting the proposal from the Commission, minimum wages benefiting mostly women in the low income sectors and care deal for Europe, radically rethinking the value of paid and of unpaid work. So let us build those bridges, so that we can finally achieve gender equality in 2030 as planned.

name: Martin Hojsík (Renew).
text: – Madam President. Women are the heroines of the pandemic. We stand on sisters and nannies who are more at the old and sick than with the family. To teachers who save our children's education. Women who, in addition to their jobs, also became teachers and cooks to take care of their family during the lockdown. After all, even a career has suffered or found itself in a violent prison. Women were heroes long before the pandemic. We still tolerate that they are not fairly assessed. We tolerate that they have two jobs, but they are paid for only one. We tolerate our neighbour living with a rapist, or tolerating that women's voices are silenced and their rights suppressed. As if that were not enough, in Slovakia, but also in Poland, governments are making the situation of women worse. Instead of tackling domestic violence, they are trying to restrict women's reproductive rights. They haunt Istanbul and cut the word "gender" from government policies. It's as if the witch hunt has returned, and the hostages are women and their rights. Enough. Gender equality is a traditional European value, because we are all equal.

name: Filip De Man (ID).
text: Mr President, first I apologise. I was born Filip De Man. I'm sorry about that. Anyway, the gender resolution, with a whopping 92 considerations and 128 recommendations. Gender seems to be the most pressing problem in Europe. Quod nun. Nowhere in the world do women enjoy so many rights. The main posts here are for Ursula von der Leyen, Christine Lagarde, Angela Merkel. I think the gender thing should stop. I even read recently that the card game should become gender neutral, because the gentleman is more than the lady. Soon the European national anthem will have to be rewritten because All Menschen became Brüder. Why not Schwestern?  While we are engaged outside the EU in spearhead robotics and quantum communication, we are, as in Constantinople, concerned with the gender of angels, with the Ottomans on our doorstep. It is part of the culture war in which the capitalist globalists and the multicultural left undermine our unique civilization, partly because of this gender madness, the cancel culture, the woke activists ...  Anyway, ladies and gentlemen, I'll do an encore and decide like the black preacher in the American congress: A-men and A-woman.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, if I’m allowed, just give me five seconds to say: aren’t we all overly joyful about the historic moment that happened yesterday, where for the first time a woman became US Vice—President, and on top of that, a Black and Asian-American woman. To me, it was really a moment of shattering of glass ceilings and a great moment of joy. Now, talking about the gender equality strategy: I was born in 1987 in western Germany. My mother always wanted to work and for that, a lot of barriers were put in her way. Last week, my sister became a mother for the first time, and the fact that for her, it’s going to be much easier to combine her work life and her family has a lot to do with the European Union, with a very proactive anti-discrimination policy that has really shaken up conservative countries like, for example, Germany. But today, if we’re being honest, the women in Germany are not as equal in their rights, as for example, women in France or Sweden. That is why, especially for conservative countries like Germany, we need a strong European Union. Be it on equal pay, on the fight against gender-based violence, or for sexual and reproductive rights. We need a push from Brussels, Madam Commissioner.

name: Jessica Stegrud (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner Dalli, I would like to thank you for your support. Listening to the debate on the eu's new gender equality strategy, one sometimes gets the impression that the typical EU citizen is a white middle-aged man with top jobs who does nothing but oppress, discriminate and abuse women. Then, when you look at the proposals for action, you realise that the Commission wants to move more power and resources to Brussels but not do anything about the main problems. Because while more and more men are today on an equal footing and paternity leave, and women are in charge of the Central Bank, the European Commission and Europe's most powerful country, the real challenges are elsewhere. It is not in corporate boardrooms that equality is being challenged today, but in the neighbourhoods where genital mutilation, honour violence, forced marriage and sex trafficking are a terrible reality – something you turn a blind eye to for ideological reasons. The proposals may benefit some, but do not address the greatest threats to gender equality today. Thanks!

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank all my fellow Members for these excellent reports on equality. Digitalisation is changing the economy, societies, working life and people's everyday lives. The COVID-19 crisis has only accelerated this development. We have moved on to distance learning and teleworking. Hobbies, physical activity and culture are increasingly practised online. E-commerce has increased. There is a real concern that women will take a backward look at this development if we do not inspire more girls and women in the information technology sector. It is really worrying, as the report states, that only 18% of ICT professionals in Europe are women. It will be a great loss to the European economy if women's potential is not fully realised. It is also a great loss to women's position in the labour market, and of course it affects the content of these digital services if women are not there to do them. It is therefore very important that we encourage all girls and women to choose digital sectors, ICT sectors, and this starts from a very small primary school. We need role models here, as stated in this report. There is also a need to increase continuing training in ict sectors – especially women who are already in employment – and, above all, to reform working life so that women throughout Europe have the opportunity to participate fully in the world of work and to bring that important potential, including in the field of digital services.

name: Robert Biedroń (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Poverty, violence, discrimination, unemployment, wage inequality have their gender. All this affects most women. The rule has been simple for centuries – where there is care, care and economic poverty, there are women, where there is money and power, there are men. This is clear in the European Parliament: there are 91% of women in the FEMM Committee, 28% of women in the Committee on Budgets. This can also be seen in our debate today.  I would like to ask the question: where are all these knights, gentlemen, feminists, where are all those who every day have their mouths full of platitudes to stand next to and fight with women? That is why I appeal to my colleagues: this is also our business, because it affects our grandmothers, mothers, wives and daughters. I would like to warn you: there really is a special place in hell for men who do not support women.

name: Chrysoula Zacharopoulou (Renew).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, we are talking about digitalisation, telecommuting, ecological transition, mobility. The coronavirus crisis is causing accelerated socio-economic and cultural changes and we are adapting.  Will the same be true for gender equality? That is the question, because I see every day men who think, men who propose, men who decide. My fear is that we are rebuilding our societies in the same way, with old patterns.  The world needs a feminist economic recovery plan, with women thinking, with women proposing and with more women leading. Commissioner, we demand legal guarantees, levers, sanctions or rewards. It is necessary to achieve equality. Ladies and gentlemen, we have a world to reinvent. This time, we must be and we will be protagonists.

name: Gwendoline Delbos-Corfield (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, these inequalities between men and women we bear in everyday life, these inequalities that have shaped our societies, could be even worse in the digital space. Algorithms have been overwhelmingly designed by white men. Amazon has discovered that one of the algorithms they were using to hire staff was simply penalising all female candidates. Facial recognition systems are dramatically and dangerously discriminatory because they are built out of data from white men’s faces. So if you present these tools with non—white or female features they will simply get all confused and will mistake one woman for another. Neutrality of technology is a sad fairy tale, a nasty one, and if we do decide to stay ignorant to these biases, the digital world will simply reproduce and amplify all the discrimination, injustices and sadness we are fighting against elsewhere. So we need public policies to prevent this from happening.

name: Margarita de la Pisa Carrión (ECR).
text: – Madam President, what does gender equality mean in the context of gender ideology and the gender perspective? Well, it is not known, because it is not coherent, since sometimes the concept of gender is used to refer to women. That said, victimized. Others, to dissociate the biological sex of the person, inventing as many categories as ways of feeling. It is an emotivist theory, with no scientific basis and against nature. We are talking about an ideology that claims to defend equality, but then highlights only differences, creates gaps, compares us, confronts women against man, generating loneliness and hopelessness. Let us admire the beauty of our complementarity, the relationships of trust, the unity. Why don't we listen to people's longings respecting our natural identity? Let's highlight femininity, motherhood. Let's protect life! All civilizations have done it. Don't manipulate us. We are not genetic engineering products.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Madam President, 2020 was tough for women. It pushed women out of the labour market more often than men and we know that job losses during a crisis have long—term lasting effects. Women might never get back what they have lost in terms of their professional careers and salaries. The pandemic created a situation that might require new ways of moving toward labour opportunities and getting women involved in the digital transition.  As the Commissioner is aware, we are at a moment when an important gender skills gap could further grow, we must go the extra mile and multiply efforts to ensure that the digital upskilling of women is not just an afterthought, but a clear priority. If the gap grows, it will be a loss for an entire society, not only women. We are now in the crucial time of planning for the New Generation EU. This strategy must be inclusive of women’s talents, gifts and skills, but we do not have a critical mass of women in decision-making bodies so we must remain particularly vigilant, and ensure that reforms and policies in response to the crisis put an emphasis on engaging women in digital technologies because that gap must not grow. Let me conclude by underlining that digital skills should be seen in the context of a fast—changing society, emerging new needs, new patterns of relations, the growing importance of social skills and a more collaborative society. We must remember that this is an environment where women thrive.

name: Lina Gálvez Muñoz (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Dalli, the COVID crisis, like any other crisis, is having a very unequal impact on people depending on the different axes of inequality, especially gender.  We know that the worst part of the labour markets are being taken away by women who, moreover, continue to support most of the domestic and care work, which has intensified greatly during the confinements.  That is why we need the European Strategy for Gender Equality to serve definitively to ensure gender mains in recovery, transformation and resilience plans; laws, policies and the budget; and, above all, for us to move forward in an assistance pact. Let us add to the green and digital twin transitions, which vertebrate our political action now in Europe, a third transition to a new social organization of care, where they do not fall naturally, unrecognized and unpaid in women.

name: Radka Maxová (Renew).
text: – Madam President, the current coronavirus pandemic has affected society as a whole, but men and women have certainly not moved Europe forward differently and in gender equality. Women have a pivotal role in solving the current crisis, and their economic strength will be crucial if we want to deal with the consequences of the pandemic. I therefore recall our call for the rapid implementation of the Directive on the combination of family and working life in individual Member States, for the unblocking of negotiations on key documents, such as the call for ratification of the Istanbul Convention and the call for greater support for women's participation in digitalisation, in the study of technical disciplines and in the Green Deal. Last but not least, I ask the Commission to submit without further delay a proposal for binding measures on pay transparency. I believe that we have a chance to get out of the crisis as a society without stereotypes, which does not define a role for women and does not pave the way for marginalisation or domestic violence, which, unfortunately, has increased considerably in this crisis. But we have to want to.

name: Sylwia Spurek (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Mrs Komisarko, i would like to thank you for your comments. Violence against women is a violation of fundamental human rights. I will continue to do so until every woman in the European Union is safe in her own home. Meanwhile, the scale of domestic violence has almost tripled recently. This data is not only the result of the COVID-19 pandemic. This is evidence of our inability to combat violence against women.  The objectives set out in the Gender Equality Strategy may change this. However, we need not only words, not just declarations of commitment and determination, but action: the ratification by the Union of the Istanbul Convention, the extension of the catalogue of Eurocrime to gender-based violence, the strengthening of the guarantee of the Victims' Rights Directive. I made these and other demands in my letter to President Ursula von der Leyen and I will be obliged for the opportunity to talk about them with Mrs Dalli. This letter was signed by almost 60,000 Poles and Poles. It's with them, I repeat, I hold the women's side.

name: Isabel Benjumea Benjumea (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, since I arrived in this Parliament there has not been a single session in which no issue on gender equality has been discussed or voted on. And I wonder whether this saturation cannot lead to the devaluation of such an important issue as freedom and equal opportunities, while fostering a false perception that women in Europe are victims and therefore need special protection. And no. In Europe, women are not born victims. We are not born victims, because in Europe we enjoy liberal democracy and its regime of freedoms and rights. It is important to point out this European context in order to understand how fortunate we are to the women who have been born on this continent and at this time, how privileged we are to live an area of freedom where each of us can achieve its dreams — the dreams it desires according to its merit and capacity — where each of us can compete on equal opportunities with anyone. Out of thanks to history, for thanking the men and women who worked to build this European project, and also out of respect for the women who still suffer persecution, marginalization and inequality elsewhere in the world, I cannot and cannot feel inferior in Europe. And since I don't feel like a victim of anything or inferior to anyone, I don't need to be imposed on a fee or benefit from positive discrimination. We are not born victims in Europe. Let us not victimize women and defend equality between men and women, equal opportunities and rights and freedoms.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we are faced with an enormous responsibility towards future generations, towards future girls and future women. This crisis gives us the opportunity to repair the social, economic and structural gaps that we have been carrying with us for a long time, to strengthen Europe and finally to put an end to all those discriminations that are unacceptable, that undermine the rule of law and the founding values of the Union. I would like to say this to some of my fellow Members who have spoken here this morning: discrimination undermines Europe's founding values. That is why we urgently need concrete and binding measures, Commissioner. We are already familiar with these measures: they are the ratification of the Istanbul Convention by the Eu ropean Union, the inclusion of gender-based violence among offences of European competence, the directive on wage transparency – the proposal for which we are still awaiting and for which I repeat my request today, Commissioner – the unblocking of the Women on Boards Directive and many others. We cannot afford any more delays.

name: Sylvie Brunet (Renew).
text: Madam President, dear Commissioner Dalli, ladies and gentlemen, finally a European Union strategy for equality between women and men is unfolding, and I welcome this. This strategy must be measured in concrete terms in strengthening European standards for non-financial information. Now let's talk about timetables and priorities, especially since COVID-19 has particularly affected women: 70% of the world's health and social services personnel are women and we have seen with sadness the increase in domestic violence. We are still waiting for the Commission's proposal on binding measures for transparency of remuneration. It was due to be presented before the end of 2020 and today it is not on the Commission's college agenda for the next two months, when there is still 16% of the average hourly wage between women and men in Europe. It should be noted that some Member States are already leading the way. France, especially with the index of professional equality, but also Germany, Finland and others. The Union must further advance women's economic emancipation and women's rights, with, of course, also the unblocking of the Women on Boards Directive and the creation of a gender equality council.

name: Henrike Hahn (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Corona pandemic is hitting people in Europe hard, but women are hitting them particularly hard. COVID—19 deepens inequalities. Women bear the brunt of care for children and the elderly. And that is even more true now than before. Women earn less, they can set aside less for prevention, and they have a higher risk of poverty. Millions of jobs are disappearing in the economic crisis. And yes, we need measures in Europe to make the economy resilient, competitive and sustainable. But these measures must ensure an equal economic situation for women. If we are to boost the economy now, it is women who must benefit from it. We need gender budgeting. Stop the gender pay gap and then wage transparency! We now have a Green Deal, but what we also need is a care deal for Europe. This is timely. Because the future of Europe is female.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Madam President, gender equality is not just a great goal, it is not yet a strategy, a policy of the European Union; And we all have a duty and an obligation to defend it. After all, the fathers and founders of the European Union have been able to incorporate gender equality into the Treaty of Rome, that is to say 64 years ago.  The fact that 100% full gender equality has not been achieved in the European Union in 64 years is a huge deficit and a stigma for the European Union itself. It is offensive and provocative at the same time for the European Institute for Gender Equality to record that we are at 65.7%, halfway to achieving the obvious: equal rights, gender equality, equal pay. 16.3% less pay for women is the rate recorded in the European Union. I believe that the happiest moment of my life will be the one when I am in the European Parliament, Commissioner, and you will announce that all this has been implemented at 100% for the European Union.  A Union of principles, values, culture cannot have this huge gap and deficit, carry it on its shoulders and not take decisive and drastic measures to cover it up and resolve it. A key and important measure would be to include the gender dimension in the budget; We're talking about a digital divide. The digital transition is made with this money given by European citizens, men and women, and the gender dimension is not included.  However, you must also send a strict directive to all Member States: those who do not apply gender equality will be severely penalised by the European Union. Only in this way will we put gender equality into practice and together we will truly feel proud European citizens, proud... (the President removes the floor from the speaker).

name: Vera Tax (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I cannot stand cases that are unfair. I'm trying to change that. So the pay gap. In the Netherlands and in the EU, women are paid about 15% less than men for their work. On a working life, that is about 300 000 euros. This is so unfair that Commission President Ursula von der Leyen promised in her very first speech: 'In the first 100 days of my mandate, I will make proposals to oblige wage transparency'. Super fine! But we're over a year on now, and her promise is nowhere to be seen. Nowhere. Not even if we ask repeatedly. A silence is the reaction so far. I hear the Commissioner say today, with all due respect, 'soon'. But it's not on the 2021 agenda. So, dear Commission and Honourable President Von der Leyen, answer the simple question: when will the Law on Wage Transparency in the EU be on the table? Because that's what all women and all men deserve.

name: Στέλιος Κυμπουρόπουλος (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner Dalli, ladies and gentlemen, I speak in Greek today because the message of gender equality must be heard by every citizen of the European Union in order to understand it. Inequality is a reality that is experienced, observed, studied; we cannot look. The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union itself recognises this in Article 8: the Union must, in all its activities, aim to eliminate inequalities and promote equality between men and women.  The political debate on gender equality is a vital instrument of the democratic process taking place in this room, but also in our own house, in the national parliaments. Exploitation and violence against women through objectification and marginalisation is a phenomenon that no one in this room can dispute. Women must operate on an equal footing in society, especially through the economy, as economic participation is key to gaining their voice in a fair labour market and society.  The European Parliament is working horizontally towards gender equality, promoting the support of violence against women, including online illegal hate speech. Everyone must be equal before the law; equal pay for equal work, according to the work plan for all. Their wallet is theirs. We defend their participation in the local and external policies of the European Union.  The European Union speaks with one voice about the position of women everywhere. Equality, at all levels and in all aspects of everyday life, is the fertile ground for the well-being of a society and the springboard for its development. That's what we're fighting to do from here.

name: Alessandra Moretti (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, COVID-19 also does not like gender equality. However, the recovery will only take place if we are able to exploit women's abilities, finally breaking that crystal roof that has been talked about for too long. That is why Next Generation EU will have to provide for half of the resources to be invested in gender policies, as the movements of #HalfOfIt or the Right Medium are asking us to do. We will have no other opportunity to guarantee girls to live in a women-friendly society, that society in which there is still too much discrimination today. And we, who have the privilege of being in this House, have a moral and political duty to set an example by starting a real process of emancipation in favour of women. European funds should be used in services for reconciling work and family, school, training, research, work and equal pay, both of which are the first real form of freedom and autonomy. If we want gender mainstreaming, initiated by the first female President of the European Commission, to really be a turning point, we must take action with a strong spirit of cross-party lobbying. The pandemic is europe's worst crisis since the war. We need everyone's contribution to overcoming it, especially that of women.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all Members for this insightful debate today. We can say that we are really one voice on this important matter.  The Commission welcomes these reports and discussions and I thank all of you involved for the great work done and for your commitment to gender equality. Your suggestions and insights buttress the Commission’s work in its fight for equality. We must ensure that every step we take is a step forward towards a more gender—equal Europe.  I thank you again, and I look forward to a year of work where we shall implement all that we have spoken about today in order to strengthen equality so that we will really have a union of equality.

name: Przewodnicząca. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 21 January 2021. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Christine Anderson (ID)
text: in writing. – This report seeks to highlight the idea that the small percentage of women involved in ICT/ STEM is primarily due to “gender stereotypes”. This reasoning is missing two crucial elements: Choice: Graphs and figures, don’t tell a person’s full story. If lack of self-confidence may play a part in the professional path taken by women, we can’t overlook the fact that education and career are first of all the result of a personal choice, based upon preferences and competences. Forcing women to engage in career paths that they might not feel particularly interested in, is counterproductive and anti-democratic. In addition, it is in contradiction with Article 15 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU, which enshrines the freedom to choose an occupation and right to engage in work Focus on sexual harassment: Though cyber violence is addressed in articles 28 through 31 of the report, it is overrun by ideology: The portion of articles suggests to combat cyber violence through “comprehensive sexual and relationship education”. This is yet again a way of pushing for more “gender ideology” under the guise of protecting women, and ultimately putting the needs of the digital Labour Market above women’s choice of career.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – We are very pleased that the Commission has adopted a communication entitled 'Equality Union: A European Union of Equalities. Gender Equality Strategy 2020-2025" in the first 100 days after the Commission's work begins. It is a strong sign of political will in the implementation of EU gender equality policies and a convincing, clear and ambitious policy framework aimed at further implementing women's rights and gender equality and combating attacks in this area. We support the Commission's objective of creating a European Union in which people, regardless of their diversity, are not exposed to discrimination and structural inequalities. To date, we have many unresolved problems in the area of gender equality . Women continue to earn less than men , their pensions are significantly lower than those of men and they are at risk of poverty in old age. On the shoulders of women, the care of dependants, the burden of the household and these activities are not remunerated. This is wrong and we need to resolve it. The proper implementation of the Work-Life Balance Directive is particularly important and we hope that the Commission will closely monitor the proper transposition and proper implementation of this directive in the Member States. The Istanbul Convention is a great disgrace to the EU as a whole , as some Member States have so far not ratified it. This sends a very bad signal and undermines our efforts to combat violence against women. We expect the Commission to actively cooperate with the Member States to complete the ratification process as soon as possible.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE)
text: Written. – Mr President, it is clear that the coronavirus pandemic has hit women and older people in particular. There are serious concerns about the rise of intimate partner and domestic violence in Europe, especially during social closures. For everyone, home is not a safe place. Hate speech online is also on the rise and women and girls are also victims of gendered violence online. All hate speech must be criminalized. The Committee on Gender Equality proposes a number of measures in the reports we are debated today: legislation to combat all gender-based violence, an action plan to close the gender pay gap, and an action plan to improve wages and working conditions in women-oriented sectors such as health care. An alarm system and continuous monitoring of the progress of women's rights should be carried out. The last few years have shown that we cannot take the progress of equality for granted, but we must work to promote it every day. There are also forces in Europe that are trying to erode the progress already made, for example in the area of sexual health and rights. We expect effective actions on equality from the Commission, the Council and the Member States.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (PPE)
text: Writing. – Ladies and gentlemen, today we are debating in the European Parliament three crucial dossiers of the Committee on Women and Gender Equality, covering a wide range of issues of inequality against women in different areas, setting important objectives for which we must fight consistently, away from stereotypes and social remnants.  Unfortunately, the pandemic has led to a setback and its economic consequences are expected to hit women harder than men. The most serious concerns are raised by the reported increase in violence against women across Europe, in particular domestic violence, when victims have been locked up with their abusers for weeks or months due to quarantine and travel restriction measures.  In this context, and as Vice-Chairman of the Committee on Women and Gender Equality, I call for and consider it necessary to integrate the gender dimension into the Union's new economic tools to tackle the crisis geared to women's needs. Above all, however, I call on all women who have suffered or have suffered violence or any form of sexual abuse or harassment to courageously report such incidents and offences, without fear of social stigmatisation from sick consciences and outdated mentalities. Our values and culture call for zero tolerance for violence.

name: Przewodnicząca. –
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on repression against the democratic opposition in Hong Kong (2021/2505(RSP)).

name: Marco Campomenosi
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Commissioner Dalli for being with us today, because the situation in Hong Kong is very serious. The concept, which we have defended for a long time, of a country and two systems is in real danger: I believe that many members agree with me on this, and I believe that all the resolutions tabled by the groups go in the same direction. Lawyers, journalists, political activists and young people are being deprived of their freedom, mainly as a result of the entry into force of the National Security Act, which jeopardises Hong Kong's autonomy, which was defended by the British-Chinese exit agreement. I therefore call for cooperation with the United Kingdom and the US Administration which, I imagine, will follow the pace of relations with China followed by the outgoing administration. And then I can only underline, as a member of the Committee on International Trade, the unease that many of us, including many governments, have suffered with regard to an acceleration in the conclusion of the EU-China investment negotiations, which surprised us a little at the end of the year. This was probably not the right time to give China such a result. I will end with the words of a missionary who has been in China for forty years, Franco Mella, who has been protesting for a long time in front of the prisons where many activists are imprisoned and who invites us not to let these people lose hope.

name: Manu Pineda
text: Author. – Madam President, I am not going to go into the substance of the debate from here, because I understand that even those who have driven it are not important. You have access to the text we have presented.  The issue of Hong Kong, which ceased to be a European colony thirty years ago, is brought here for the umpteenth time. It's just an excuse. In each plenary you will find one to talk about China.  This debate reflects the colonial vocation of some groups acting as if Europe is still the metropolis that can impose its decisions on China, and puts its servileness to the United States above the interests of European workers and businesses.  It does not seem very clever to assault and insult the People's Republic of China in every plenary. If we really want to build a multipolar world, we need to strengthen our relations with Beijing. Because the dangers of the current unilateral model are well known, for example, the 12,000 Airbus workers in Europe who can stay on the street for America's blackmail of the European aerospace sector.  The New Silk Road, a project that seems destined to transform how countries relate to each other, gives us an opportunity we should not despise. It is urgent to move from the current model, in which the strongest appropriates the resources of others by imposing their law, to one based on mutual benefit and horizontal relations.  We welcome the European Union-China strategic agreement and hope that, in the face of the outburrs of some here, we can continue to work in a comprehensive order based on international law, the fight against climate change, peace and the sovereignty of the peoples.

name: Nathalie Loiseau
text: Author. Madam President, in a few weeks we have learned a lot about China. We have learned that the Chinese Communist Party is afraid of freedom, even in a small territory of 7 million people, Hong Kong. The Chinese government prefers the freedom to repress to the freedom to express itself.  We have learned that China is not complying with its international commitments on Hong Kong, made under the joint declaration with the United Kingdom. We have learned that the Chinese Communist Party is afraid of transparency. How long and difficult did it take for WHO to finally send a mission to Wuhan to investigate the origins of the COVID-19 pandemic, whose global dimension and disastrous consequences justify that all light be shed wherever necessary? Finally, we have learned that China denies the obvious, that of the atrocious fate reserved for the Uighur people.  All of this, we have undoubtedly learned at the very moment when China is reaching an investment agreement with the European Union. This agreement raises doubts among many of us, because what we have learned, we will not be able to ignore, because in this agreement there is a text that we are still waiting for, but there is also a context. And in this Parliament, there is a democracy, European democracy that expresses itself and says what it has to say.

name: Bert-Jan Ruissen
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, it is becoming increasingly clear that China is using the draconian new security law in Hong Kong to silence the democratic opposition and seriously restrict the freedoms of Hong Kong people. Under the guise of "countering state subverting behaviour", anyone who is critical of them is silenced. How far is this going to go? In China, religious minorities are suffering from charges based on national security law. Is this curtailment of religious freedoms going to become a reality in Hong Kong? That is our great fear. The EU, together with the international community, must join forces and take a strong stand. So do not conclude an investment agreement with vague promises on human rights at a time when the human rights situation in China is in the deepest valley for decades. But take targeted action against all those responsible for the violations of fundamental rights of Hong Kongers and Chinese.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Developments in Hong Kong must wake us up. The repression of the opposition movement and the structured action against pro-democracy organisations are a massive interference with the fundamental rights of the Hong Kong people. The Chinese authorities are thus undermining the agreed autonomy of the Special Administrative Zone immensely. It is significant that the national security law is being used to arrest unwelcome people and censor freedom of expression. With today's resolution, the European Parliament has reinforced its position that the actions of the leaders of China and the Hong Kong administration do not go unnoticed. We insist that the national security law, which with its far-reaching powers massively curtails the fundamental rights of the Hong Kong Constitution, must be repealed. In addition, all of the wrongly detained opponents must be released immediately and the charges based on the National Security Act must be dropped. In view of the increasing pressure on the democratic forces in Hong Kong, the Council must consider targeted sanctions against the decision-makers in the Hong Kong administration as the next measure. And we expect the issues of fundamental rights to also be taken into account in the forthcoming agreements with China. Because trade is important, yes, but not at any price.

name: Jordi Solé
text: author. – Madam President, we stand by the people of Hong Kong, by the many struggling for democracy, for their fundamental rights and for the right to keep enjoying a high degree of sub-government. It has become crystal clear that China is overly using the national security law as an instrument to suppress dissent and political pluralism.  We have witnessed incarcerations, disqualification of lawmakers, pressure of the media and even prosecution abroad. All this in clear violation of the Sino-British Joint Declaration and the basic law. It’s time for the EU to take further actions, for instance, by using the new human rights sanctions regime. And, one last remark. With increasing human rights violations happening in China, rushing to reach an agreement on investments as the Council did, might harm our credibility as a global human rights actor. When scrutinising the agreement and voting on it, this Parliament cannot ignore the worrying situation of human rights in China.

name: Miriam Lexmann
text: author. – Madam President, let me first of all thank colleagues from all across the political groups for the excellent cooperation on this urgency resolution.  Article 21 of the EU Treaties clearly states that the Union’s external action shall be guided by the values and principles on which the Union was founded – in particular, democracy, rule of law, the universality of human rights, fundamental freedoms, and respect for human dignity.  Dear colleagues, the Chinese Communist Party and its collaborators in Hong Kong continue to strip away the city’s high degree of autonomy and suppress Hong Kongers’ freedoms, including political rights. They are using the so—called ‘National Security Law’ as a pretext to destroy Hong Kong’s democracy and put in jail pro—democratic activists and politicians.  These developments are highly worrying. It is no longer sufficient to be concerned. We also have to learn a lesson that pure economic engagement is not a way of supporting democracy and human rights, as we used to think. If the Union wants to be a credible actor, and truly engage in value—based foreign policy, we must use our economic position as the leverage to support those who are oppressed, rather than to reward human rights abusers. Otherwise, we might become morally co—responsible for these crimes and abuses.  To support the people of Hong Kong, our steps must include: implementing the July 2020 Council Conclusions on Hong Kong, including the lifeboat scheme, suspension of extradition treaties and support for civil society; using the Magnitsky Act to sanction Carrie Lam and other Chinese and Hong Kong officials; and make it clear to the Chinese Communist Party that this House will take human rights into consideration when asked to endorse the investment agreement and any future agreement with China and other regimes supressing human rights. It is time for the European Union to act. It is time to defend freedom. It is time to stand with Hong Kong.

name: Seán Kelly
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, good morning, Brussels and good morning, Hong Kong.  The Hong Kong police arrested 53 representatives of the democratic opposition and activists on charges of subversion under the national security law for Hong Kong, freezing many assets relating to these individuals. This is the latest in a long series of arrests of the  democratic opposition and other actions aimed at undermining democratic institutions in Hong Kong. It’s not just on the streets where censorship is taking place, but over the internet as pro-democracy websites are blocked, further limiting freedom of expression and access to information, which have damaging consequences for both civil liberties and democracy. The unilateral introduction of national security legislation by the Government in Beijing is an attack on the city of Hong Kong’s autonomy, rule of law and fundamental freedoms, and degrades the integrity of one country, two systems, which is a breach of China’s commitments and obligations under international law.  With my colleague, Barry Andrews, I would also like to highlight the case of Richard O’Halloran, an Irish citizen and father of four from Dublin, who has been refused permission to leave China since March 2019. Richard has not been arrested, charged or personally accused of any wrongdoing; he was just unfortunate enough to be caught up in an investigation into another individual, whom he had never met during the period on which to investigation is focused. I would call on the Chinese Government to allow Mr O’Halloran to come home as there is no legitimate reason for him to be kept against his will. I also call on the Chinese Government to listen carefully to what the Members of Parliament are saying today and to act accordingly. That is in the best interests of everybody and good relations with the European Union. Good morning and the best of luck to the people of Hong Kong.

name: Isabel Santos
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, the worst fears expressed in this House seven months ago have taken place. The entry into force of the National Security Act on Hong Kong territory has caused a vertiginous degradation of the rights and fundamental freedoms of the region's inhabitants.  Since then, and in just this short time, more than 400 activist politicians have been the target of intimidation, arbitrary arrests and convictions. I draw your attention to the case of the 12 pro-democracy activists captured by China, of whom 10 have been sentenced to prison for illegal crossing of continental waters. Among these is Tsz Lun Kok, a young citizen of Hong Kong, also with Portuguese nationality, therefore, a European citizen.  I join my voice with the High Representative in the call for the immediate release of all these young people, but the European Union must take a firm and unrelenting approach, with consequences, of all human rights violations in Hong Kong and also in mainland China, Tibet and Xinjiang.

name: Svenja Hahn
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, we parliamentarians have been very vocal. We support the people of Hong Kong fearlessly standing up for their democracy. The democracy that is being cracked down on by China day by day, with the utmost disrespect for the struggle for freedom, by breaking international law. It’s time that the Commission and the Member States acted. It’s time you turned words into action. So, here’s a reminder: work with the US towards defending liberal democracy against a systemic rival. Use the human rights mechanism to sanction responsible individuals in China and their accomplices in Hong Kong. Insist that civil and political rights are restored. The democratic opposition must be freed and allowed to run in the next elections. Brave people of Hong Kong, the European Parliament will keep fighting for you with the tools of democracy that you are deprived of. Freedom will prevail. We stand by your side.

name: Gunnar Beck
text: on behalf of the ID Group. – Madam President, this House has a habit of debating matters in faraway places of which we know little and about which we can do nothing. Human rights in Hong Kong is such a topic and for once, you’re right. The situation does raise concerns. Yet as we speak, the EU is concluding a new investment treaty with China, and Germany depends on exports to China to bankroll the euro area. The EU cannot even afford imposing sanctions on China. So why are we discussing human rights in Hong Kong at all?  The EU is censoring free speech and social media are silencing dissent. Some Member States are imprisoning their own citizens for holding referenda. Others don’t allow referenda at all, and in Germany the biggest opposition party is placed under surveillance for opposing immigration in a year of major elections, and in Germany too, a law is passed to punish vilification of the EU’s flag and symbols, with three years in prison.  Countries used to start wars to overcome internal strife and dissent. Today, the West finds fault with the rest to exert soft power, yet Western liberal democracy is no longer liberal and long ceased to be democratic. The West is trying to pull a trick that’s no longer working.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, this resolution that we’re debating sends one clear central message: the European Parliament will continue to stand with Hong Kong. We’re underscoring this stance by clearly saying that the EU must act upon our words. We must make use of the newly introduced global human rights sanctions mechanism to sanction those people, including in particular Carrie Lam, that are violating human rights in Hong Kong. When we debate the EU—China Comprehensive Agreement on Investment (CAI), we will take human rights into account, and I can’t see how the present text suffices to our standards.  One last sentence to some panda huggers from ID and GUE: if you hate your own political system so much that you think you have to find excuses for acting on behalf of a foreign aggressive power, that’s not positive, that’s not progressive, that is despicable.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Honourable Members, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwab, for his excellent work. I have been to Hong Kong twice already at a time when it was part of the People's Republic of China, albeit of course with great autonomy. I would also remind you – because this has not been the case in the speeches so far – that there is a special EU Hong Kong Friendship Group in our Parliament. I am honored to be a member of it. I think that these politicians, those public figures who criticised the fact that at a time when Hong Kong was part of the British Empire, the Governor was appointed british queen. Those who did not do so then, today, frankly, sound a bit hypocritical. I believe that it is necessary to promote human rights in Hong Kong. That's for granted.

name: Emmanuel Maurel
text: on behalf of the band The Left. Madam President, one country, two systems was the commitment that China made to the international community at the time of Hong Kong's handover in 1997. This commitment has not been respected, this word has not been kept, but nothing is discovered. This is not the first time that China has deliberately violated the rules it had committed to abide by. This is the case at the WTO or WHO, and it will also be tomorrow at the ILO. And despite this, European leaders who are so quick to denounce foreign dictatorships are turning a blind eye, either because they believe that China can be blindly trusted - and they are wrong - or because they are cynical and consider that the size and wealth of the country justify this collective amnesia. And that's the case when you sign an investment agreement in secret. This is not only an economic mistake, it is also a political fault in view of the situation in Hong Kong, in view of the fate of the persecuted Uighurs, also in the eyes of wuhan whistleblowers who have been silenced. So Europe needs to wake up and stop turning a blind eye.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as early as 30 June 2020, when the infamous National Security Law was imposed by the Beijing authorities, one of the best-known faces of activists from the former British colony, Joshua Wong, warned us that this would represent the end of Hong Kong and the beginning of terror. Since then, in fact, the situation has only worsened: since December Joshua has been in prison for the umpteenth time, along with many other activists, and a few weeks ago we saw the arrest by the government of 53 pro-democracy politicians on the basis of the extremely broad and vague provisions of this draconian law. The people of Hong Kong have clearly expressed their peaceful demands for freedom and autonomy, but the authorities have always chosen to respond with increasing repression and violence, and the total asymmetry of power between Beijing and Hong Kong makes this situation even more complex. My question is, then, how did we forget this issue in the last investment agreement with China? How did we allow our efforts to become rhetorical? This hong kong struggle is not just a struggle that belongs to the people living there, it is a struggle of all those who believe in democracy and the defence of human rights globally.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, yesterday the vast majority of this European Parliament celebrated as good news and a window of hope biden's arrival at the White House and celebrated Trump's departure, whose denial of cooperation with the European Union and multilateralism is surely the context of strategic autonomy, the diplomacy of the European Union from which the comprehensive investment agreement that the European Union signs with China in December brings 2020. But under no circumstances can this context prejudice the European Union's clear commitment to human rights and its protest at the arbitrary and illegal detention of journalists, students, human rights lawyers and candidates for local elections, which clearly violates international law, the 1984 Sino-British agreement and China's 1997 status as a Special Region for Hong Kong , which guarantees you plural elections and an independent judiciary. And so this is the moment when the European Parliament has to raise its voice to say that no agreement can justify looking the other way. And that this Parliament takes its democratic commitment to human rights very seriously. In China and everywhere.

name: Bernard Guetta (Renew).
text: Madam President, let's call a spade a spade. In debating this morning the political repression in Hong Kong, we are talking about an ascending power that sits on the "one country, two systems" agreement, holds one million Uighurs in forced labour camps, threatens Taiwan, projects itself in the South China Sea and says without shame that dictatorship would be preferable to freedom. For democracy, Mr Xi's regime is a challenge like no other, and therefore the question of the investment agreement arises to us. We will be debating for months its economic clauses and its very principle, but our political duty, as parliamentarians, is to tell Mr Xi now that we will not be able to ratify this agreement until his regime has ratified international conventions against forced labour.  It is a sine qua non condition on which we can agree in no time. So my dear colleagues, let's do it! This clear message, let's deliver it now!

name: Yannick Jadot (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this resolution says how the European Parliament has never resigned itself to repression in Hong Kong and the rest of China. It is also a terrible admission of failure because despite our denunciations, the dictatorship has never been so brutal, violent, cynical in China. And since we are talking about cynicism, how can we accept that Angela Merkel and Emmanuel Macron forget the worst dictatorship in the world, forget its denunciations, forget the values of Europe to sell cars, private health homes or surveillance systems? Colleagues, we cannot denounce a political regime on the one hand and, on the other hand, do business in cynicism. This Parliament today must not simply question the investment agreement with China: it must denounce it! It is a mistake of Europe's democratic, economic, digital and energy sovereignty. This is, as has been said, a political fault! So let's suspend all discussions, negotiations with China now.

name: Assita Kanko (ECR).
text: – Madam President, when it comes to human rights, the EU has two faces. It’s happy to issue statements of concern, passing its judgment on countries around the world, but our support for democracy and human rights is less vociferous when it comes to selling German cars. Brave young men and women stand on the front lines of the battle between freedom and autocracy. They include Joshua Wong, Agnes Chow and Ivan Lam, currently in jail for defending the democracy that we all take for granted here. What are we doing to support them? What signal are we sending to them, when we close our eyes and sign an investment agreement with the very regime that is trampling over democracy in its neighbourhood, murdering Uighurs and threatening democratic Taiwan? What actions will the EU take regarding that investment agreement with China if the PRC continues to break human rights and international labour laws? Know that Hong Kong is a test of the resolve of the free world. Right now, the EU is shamefully failing that test and I deeply feel ashamed for that?

name: Clara Ponsatí Obiols (NI).
text: – Madam President, the democracy movement of Hong Kong has the genuine sympathy and solidarity of the Catalans. Their fight against authoritarianism for democracy and self-determination is our fight. But the people of Hong Kong are enduring massive arrests, exile, the criminalisation of fundamental rights like the freedom of assembly and interference in their electoral processes — this is all too familiar to us as well. While Beijing crushes democracy in Hong Kong, what message do they get from the EU? A rushed conclusion to the investment agreement! This sends a very clear message that human rights and violations are perhaps unpleasant, but they are not going to be an obstacle for businesses. The EU must stop sending these mixed messages, just paying lip service to their commitment to democracy and human rights. This Parliament must put on hold the EU investment agreement, and this Parliament must support the Uighur people and declare it a genocide.

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the Chinese regime never hesitates to violate human rights and international law. The case of Hong Kong is one of the many violations of human rights and international law. The speedy deterioration in Hong Kong is worrying. The oppressive Chinese regime must immediately release all political prisoners, including the immediate and unconditional release of the opposition members of the Parliament of Hong Kong and also the release of the Swedish bookseller Gui Minhai in prison in the PRC. Introduction of the national security legislation in Hong Kong is a shame. The ‘one country, two systems’ principle must be respected. It is time for the EU and the Member States to act. How much more should the people of Hong Kong suffer until the world acts? It shouldn’t matter how big a country is geographically, demographically or economically: human rights and international law are universal and must always apply.

name: Markéta Gregorová (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, China has shown us enough. It showed us everything we Europeans fought in the past: concentration camps, genocide, taking one’s country for its own, sending people to jail for their opinions, creating causes to subdue the population. Ring any bells? Let me apologise to Hong Kong citizens for talking mainly about China when all our eyes should be on you. But this is simply not enough. We have another resolution condemning Beijing’s actions, while our EU colleagues are shaking hands with Xi Jinping, striking pompous investment deals. Later today, we will talk about the deteriorating situation in Vietnam.  Some tried to persuade me last year that a trade deal would help human rights. Man, were they wrong. Are we really making the same mistake again? Do you really not care? Ms von der Leyen, Mr Macron, Ms Merkel, Mr Michel, this is not my European Union. Our values are not for sale.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you to the honourable Members of this Parliament. The situation in Hong Kong is deteriorating very fast, as you all rightly pointed out. On 6 January, the authorities conducted mass arrests under the National Security Law. The 53 arrested stand accused of subversion for participating in the pro—democracy primary elections held in July 2020. The criminalisation of legitimate political activity is aimed at stifling pluralism, pro—democracy voices and the exercise of political and fundamental freedoms in Hong Kong. The arrests on 14 January of 11 individuals implicated in the attempted escape to Taiwan of 12 Hong Kongers further compounds the impression that the criminal justice system is being deployed to punish dissent. Since the imposition of the national security legislation by Beijing over Hong Kong, the EU has conveyed with the great unity its strong concerns publicly in a serious of declarations and directly to the Chinese leadership at the summit in June and the leaders’ meeting in September. The leaders’ meeting of December was not only the occasion to conclude negotiations in principle on a comprehensive agreement on investment with China but also to raise concern on Hong Kong. The EU will continue to stand firm on its values and principles, while pursuing its interests. And the same effort in July, the Council adopted an EU response package comprising a mix of measures at EU and national level, such as further scrutinising exports of sensitive equipment, suspending extradition agreements, stepping up scholarships and academic exchanges, further engaging with civil society and observing trials of pro—democracy activists. There is consensus on continuing to apply the measures and to consider additional steps in case of further deterioration. Unity and solidarity continue to prevail. We cannot let any Member State, any citizen, any Member of Parliament be singled out with respect to Hong Kong, Xinjiang or more broadly, China. By calling for the release of Swedish citizen, Gui Minhai, the EU will continue to stand firm on protecting its citizens. Coordination with like—minded democracies on Hong Kong and addressing other challenges brought along by China will continue to be a cornerstone of our approach. Hong Kong remains high on our political agenda and will be discussed at the upcoming Foreign Affairs Council on 25 January.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place after the debates.

name: Presidente. –
text: The following is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the human rights situation in Turkey, especially the case of Selahattin Demirtas and other prisoners of conscience (2021/2506(RSP)).

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: Author. – Mr President, despite the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights, Demirta has been wrongly detained since 2016.  Since then, dozens of politicians and thousands of HDP members have been arrested or imprisoned. Its mayors—legitimately elected—have been dismissed and replaced by friends of the government. And it seems that the strategy is not to stop until you get the HDP crushed. As Demirta, there are thousands of prisoners and political prisoners in Turkey, because Erdogan cares little about human rights or international regulations, and it seems that his role as guardian of European borders gives him carte blanche to do whatever he wants.  That is why we ask that the opposite be demonstrated: that Borrell should react strongly, that Borrell require a meeting with the Foreign Minister to demand the freedom of all political prisoners and Mr Demirta, that an arms embargo be approved and that accession negotiations be frozen until human rights in Turkey are respected. In short, it is shown that violating human rights has consequences.

name: Thierry Mariani
text: Author. Mr President, Turkey would suddenly become frequent again. Unfortunately, we knew that this would happen, as Chancellor Merkel's Germany has always bowed to Erdogan's pressure. Last Monday, the German Foreign Minister was on his way to Turkey. At the end of December, the same Heiko Maas refused Greece's legitimate request to impose an arms trade embargo with Turkey. It is the same one that sent Greece and Turkey back to back in the rising tension in the Mediterranean last summer, on the occasion of an umpteenth visit to Ankara.  It was Mrs Merkel who was again praised by the Turkish Foreign Minister at the NATO meeting in December. The presidency of the European Union by Mrs Merkel was therefore the occasion of a diplomatic victory for Turkey in Erdogan, and it is not by claiming today to defend some unjustly prosecuted opponents that we will make him forget. Meanwhile, Turkey continues to persecute its opponents and religious minorities, I am thinking for example of the murder of the Christian couple Simoni and Hurmuz Diril in January 2020. Turkey is doing nothing to solve this murder. Political Islamism, persecution of Christian minorities, blackmail at migration, Turkey is a danger to Europe. We will abstain on this resolution. It must not hide the reality: the German Presidency of the Union has made us capitulate to Erdogan.

name: Hermann Tertsch
text: Author. – Mr President, from here we are all going to recall the need for the release of Mr Demirta and all those political prisoners who are overcrowded in Turkish prisons. But I would also like to remind you that all these regrets we have had about Turkey for years — and, of course, in the last parliamentary term we are continually with them — do not have a real answer. We've never been through what words are. It's the same with China. We're crying here over the crushing of the opposition in China. Or it happens with Venezuela. We are dealing with that and yet we are not making progress on what it has to be, in a series of sanctions that restore the credibility of the European Union. We have talked a lot about Turkey, but no one has raised - as has to be done, once and for all - the paralysis of accession negotiations, the sine die suspension of this absurdity that we have there, with a dictatorship that is falling deeper and deeper into repression— as is the case with China; and yet we make agreements, make plans and continue with the whole export, as if nothing happened, until the next whining.

name: Sergey Lagodinsky
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The day before yesterday, I gave a speech on Alexei Navalny. I mentioned at the time that we are talking far too little about the heroes of democracy and about political prisoners. It is actually unbelievable to me, and only recently, inconceivable that I have to talk on this subject about a country with which we actually want and want to build a common European future. There are political prisoners here, too. And we must now talk about this country in the same way as we do about other countries, including Russia. It is unbelievable that we have to hold such a meeting on Turkey. But the names speak for themselves: Selahattin Demirta', Figen Yuksekda', Osman Kavala, but also lesser-known names such as Cihan Erdal or a German citizen, Gönül Örs, and her mother, who cannot get out of the country and who also face imprisonment. Our green position and my personal position is clear: Turkey's future is a European future and we need a normalisation of our relationship. But this normalization begins with human rights, begins with the rule of law, and also begins with the normalization of international law. Until that progress is made, we will not make progress with normalisation. It is a pity, but that is the fact.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: author. – Mr President, Selahattin Demirtas has been detained for over four years, based on unfounded charges and despite two rulings of the European Court of Human Rights calling for his release. His case for me is just an example of the widespread human rights abuses and the misuse of the judiciary in Turkey. Colleagues, this resolution is yet another sign of our concern with the situation in Turkey, but it’s also a sign of solidarity with those who suffer the repressive measures taken by the Erdoğan regime. You all know that this Parliament will soon deal with the annual report on Turkey and, there too, we will repeat our concerns. My main message to the Turkish authorities today, ahead of their visit to Brussels later this week, is to remind them of our resolution. I will talk to Mr Erdoğan. Mr Erdoğan, better relations are fully dependent on tangible improvements in the respect of democratic principles, the rule of law and fundamental rights inside your country. If you’re serious about turning a new page in your relations with Europe, you know what to do.

name: Nacho Sánchez Amor
text: Author. – Mr President, the HDP was a party closely linked, originally, to the Kurdish movement. And today, however, it is a party with a broad sociological basis in other progressive sectors of Turkey.  The HDP and Demirta itself have represented the decision of many prokurdos activists to abandon gun violence and to bet on action within institutions. It is a process that we know very well in Spain, because it is at the origin of ETA's democratic victory over terrorism.  In Turkey, however, this movement is continually accused of terrorism. We have tried to convince our Turkish colleagues that keeping the HDP in the institutions is vital for Turkish democracy to survive as such. It is a party that, on its own merits and against all the elements, as Urbán has recalled, now has remarkable popular support.  The case of Demirta is particular, not only because he is a leader, not only because he was a candidate from prison for president of the country, also because the European Court of Human Rights has said several times — last time, a few weeks ago — that there were no reasons for his detention and his tenure in prison and that he should be immediately released.  These days, the Turkish leaders and, surely today, the Turkish minister here in Brussels, want to show us that relations with Europe have to be resumed, that they want to return to these long-postponed democratic reforms.  We don't want any more statements. Please don't send us any more love letters. Send us facts, decisions that demonstrate the sincerity of this — apparently - renewed European bet. They fulfill their commitments to international legality and release Demirta, which is a good example of the sincerity of this European bet.

name: Peter van Dalen
text: Author. Mr President, here we are again. Another debate on the human rights situation in Turkey, again on the violation of the rights of prisoners of conscience. How many times have we held such debates, when countless journalists, politicians and spiritual leaders are behind bars in Turkey? Around 270 journalists have been detained worldwide. Forty-seven of them are trapped in Turkey and countless others have already fled. Lawyers who want to assist those journalists have little access to court documents. Social media users are also regularly arrested, and the same fate affects Erdoğan's political opponents, such as Demirtas. Spiritual leaders in Turkey are not sure of their freedom. There are mock lawsuits against church leaders and goods of monasteries are regularly expropriated. In addition, Erdoğan engages with villains such as Hamas leader Hanija. Hamas' new broadcaster, which is funded by Turkey, aims to promote Erdoğan in the Middle East. Mr President, it is clear to me: not words, but deeds. All these resolutions on the situation in Turkey make little of a living. With all these texts on paper, Erdoğan only lights up his golden fireplace. It is time for strong sanctions against the regime in Ankara. That may mean less sales by European companies of products to Turkey. Well, that's too bad. The merchant wins here often enough. Human rights, especially those of prisoners of conscience, are more important than making money from trade with dubious countries such as Turkey.

name: Tomislav Sokol
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. - Dear Chairman, the European Union brings together Member States committed to the European idea and the European way of life, including democracy and the rule of law. However, the political circumstances are such that in the immediate neighbourhood we have a state that is not committed to the values described. While the fact that Turkey has enjoyed candidate status for membership in the Union since 1999 should mean that it shares our vision of fundamental values, especially the rule of law, unfortunately this is not the case. This is evidenced by the years-long judicial farce related to the baseless detention of opposition leader Selahattin Demirtaş, who was stripped of his liberty back in 2016. In its December decision, the European Court of Human Rights unequivocally confirmed that demirtaş's imprisonment was not based on law and ordered his immediate release.  Colleagues, I hereby regret that Turkey, as our long-standing partner in preserving international peace, does not respect the decisions of the established courts. When we add to this the increasingly aggressive behaviour in the eastern Mediterranean, the increasingly difficult position of Christians, the persecution of political opponents and the connection with the Muslim Brotherhood, we can unfortunately argue that Turkey is not moving forward but is going backwards more and more.  In other words, it is time for the European Union to finally consider what long-term form of cooperation with Turkey it wants given the frequent violations of the rule of law in this country.

name: Kati Piri
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, 1 500 days – that’s how long Selahattin Demirtaş has now been in jail, ripped away from his wife, Başak, taken away for more than four years from his children, his two daughters, from his family and from his friends. Just to add to the torture, they have put him in a detention facility 1 600 kilometres away from his house. That’s as far as from here to Rome. What is his crime? His crime is to represent the voiceless people, it is to enter politics and to speak out against the authoritarianism of President Erdoğan. Is that my personal opinion? No. This opinion is shared by the highest authority on human rights in Europe. The European Court of Human Rights Grand Chamber has come to the conclusion that he must be released immediately. What is happening with HDP in Turkey? We have seen their leaders being put in jail, and their Members of Parliament, their mayors and their activists, for four years now.  I understand that the Foreign Minister of Turkey is coming for a visit to Brussels. I urge everyone entering into talks with him to put the case of Selahattin Demirtaş and Osman Kavala at the top of the agenda. It’s useless to continue to talk if there is no action from the Turkish Government side. I believe it’s time to apply pressure, which Erdoğan does understand. Selahattin, Başak – em bi te re ne, we are with you!

name: Ramona Strugariu
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, while we were preparing this resolution on Mr Demirtaş and other prisoners of conscience, a journalist named Melis Alphan was charged with terrorist propaganda and now risks 7.5 years in prison because six years ago she shared on her Instagram account a photo from a public celebration of an event broadcast by the national television during the peace process. In that photo, one could see a Kurdish flag.  This is one of the most absurd attacks on free journalism and on democracy that I have ever witnessed. I wonder for how long we can continue to keep our eyes closed and our pockets open to such blatant injustice, while Erdoğan continues to send people to jail. Millions of people did what Melis did back then. Should they all go to jail, President Erdoğan?  If Turkey claims to be a democracy, then political prisoners should be released, fundamental freedoms should be respected and free journalists should be honoured. Then we can have a dialogue. I stand with you, Melis Alphan, and with Mr Demirtaş and other people who deserve a European life, not a dictatorship.

name: Susanna Ceccardi
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are also discussing Turkey and its concept of human rights at this part-session. In recent years, Erdoğan's attitude towards Europe and other sovereign states has been no less belligerent and hostile. In spite of this, Europe and some European governments, including the Italian government, continue to want to continue the negotiations on Turkey's accession to Europe, as if we could gloss over the aggression of the Nagorno, the war in northern Syria, the drilling off Cyprus, the oppression of political opponents, and the hate speech towards the European West. They turned St. Sophia's Basilica into a mosque, an affront to a symbol of the whole Christian world. How much money have we given and are we continuing to give to Turkey? Between subsidies, aid and incentives to stop immigration, Turkey has collected more than EUR 15 billion since 2002 despite its Islamist breakthrough. Let us stop funding and arming an enemy of the West who makes a mockery of us. Let us immediately stop negotiating Turkey's entry into Europe and spend that money on our people, on our businesses and on our infrastructure.
