Some dictators do not understand the language of diplomacy, that of our human rights resolutions. They only yearn to expand their power, even to the detriment of other peoples. As far as we are concerned, Turkey has never been, is not and will never be Europe.

name: François Alfonsi
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, the political situation in Turkey is showing more worrying signs every day. The entire democratic opposition is in danger of no longer being able to stand in an election because those who win them are under threat of charges of complicity in terrorism, then detained for many years, such as Mr. Selahattin Demirtas, brilliant candidate of the Kurdish HDP party in the 2015 presidential election, then imprisoned in 2016 when he was re-elected as an MP and still in prison for five years. In the face of such democratic scandals, the European Union's first duty is to ensure that it bears no responsibility for them.  Therefore, the time has come to question the relevance of the PKK's inclusion on the list of terrorist organizations, when it cannot be blamed for any such act for a very long time. It is indeed an armed organization engaged in a territorial conflict, but it is not justified to classify it as a terrorist, except to go back several decades. This was also implemented by a court decision issued in Belgium in 2020. By withdrawing this political cover from Mr Erdogan's repression, Europe would thus give a positive signal to all the democratic opposition in Turkey.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, colleagues, listening to you, will tell themselves that this room is full of human rights fighters, people who bravely stand up to dictatorships, and people who have no fear of saying in the eyes of dictator Erdogan that he is a dictator. Alas, dear colleagues, this is not true at all. For seven years I have been telling you from this chamber and from the one in Strasbourg that Erdogan is a dictator, that he is violating human rights, that he is throwing journalists in jail, that he is fighting illegal wars everywhere, and for seven years the vast majority of you are being made that you do not see and do not hear what is happening. And when we ask you for real action on this topic, we hear the answer that Erdogan and Turkey were a strategic partner. Well, at the same time, colleagues, Erdogan is your strategic partner and you criticize him here for human rights violations. One of the two is true, can not be true both. Therefore, what needs to be done is to end the empty talk here and take real action. That means sanctions, it means ending membership negotiations because Turkey is not a European country, as we know it means finally seeing the truth and acting. The other, I say again, is empty talk.

name: Özlem Demirel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to like the Left Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the "We are not prisoners, we are hostages! The aim is to crush the opposition bloc, to prevent us from coming together. The AKP is fighting vehemently for its survival. At the next elections, the HDP and other opposition parties will send the AKP-MHP bloc into the dustbin of history! We will build democracy," said Selahattin Demirtaé from prison in the autumn of 2020. Yes, Demirtaé and countless others are hostages. They should be silenced. In Turkey, the question is: democracy or autocracy? There are currently countless meetings between REPRESENTATIVES of the EU and Turkey. It goes without saying that dialogue is needed in international relations. But there is also a need for transparency. That is why I ask: What did Heiko Maas discuss? What is the specific negotiation of Mr Borrell today with Mr Avusoglu? Will geopolitical and economic interests continue to determine EU-Turkey relations, or will the EU finally take a clear position alongside democracy and human rights? Selahattin Demirta', Gültan Koanak, Osman Kavala and many, many other political prisoners must finally be released!

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, for the umpteenth time we are here talking about Turkey.  Since the failed coup d'état in 2016, the purges of the Ankara government have not seen any setbacks. Erdoğan continues to use the event as a justification to strike at all his critics, to block and hold his opponents, and to consolidate his government. For four years, the Turkish Government has been arresting, indeed kidnapping, people affiliated to opposition groups and civil society, in particular members of the People's Democratic Party, without interruption. Now, with the COVID-19 pandemic, it has also had yet another pretext to strengthen authoritarian rule, passing new restrictive laws to limit dissent. That of Selahattin Demirtas, who has been unjustly imprisoned for four years in defiance of the judgments of the European Court of Justice, as well as those of the other courageous MEMBERS of the HDP and democratically elected mayors, are all emblematic cases, which further demonstrate not only Turkey's deafness to international appeals and the provocative attitude of its President, but also the contempt, indeed the contempt , for the rule of law and international institutions. Ladies and gentlemen, the EU has so far been far too lenient in trying to find a de facto unilateral dialogue with Turkey. There is an urgent need for a jolt of dignity in the free world, and it is urgent to understand that words are no longer enough. We have at our disposal a new effective and targeted sanctioning instrument, the so-called Magnitsky Act: if we are not prepared to use it, if we continue to use double standards and blackmail ourselves on the issue of migration, we will not only lose credibility, but it will also be our dignity that will vanish forever.

name: Στέλιος Κυμπουρόπουλος (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Turkey and the Erdogan regime are once again concerned. Selahattin Demirtas has been imprisoned since 4 November 2016 in a maximum security prison in Edirne, without having committed any offence. This is not the first time That President Erdogan has imprisoned people who do not agree with his views or believe that they are threatening him. In total, it has laid off 150,000 people and imprisoned 80,000 as alleged participants in the 2016 coup and Gulen supporters. In Turkey, the rule of law and the distinction between powers have been broken for years and the rights of Turkish citizens are being violated.  The European Council cannot ask Poland, Bulgaria and Hungary to strengthen the rule of law and at the same time allow the acceding Turkey to slip into dictatorial practices. Until when, as Europe, will we tolerate it and advocate through our silence an authoritarian regime? The voice of the European Parliament is strong and a clear message to President Erdogan.

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the case of Selahattin Demirtaş is a story about a father, a human rights lawyer and a well—respected politician, but it is also a story about people, the Kurdish people and many other people in Turkey under oppression by different governments, and currently the national conservative AKP government. Thanks to the European Court of Human Rights many have got restoration, some through economic compensation, others through freedom from imprisonment. The case of Selahattin Demirtaş is the story of a person, but also of a people.  That the Turkish Government refuses to respect the 22 December 2020 ruling of the Grand Chamber of the European Court of Human Rights is unacceptable. Commissioner Dalli, the Turkish Minister of Foreign Affairs is here these days. Will you and the High Commissioner receive my challenge to raise the issue of immediately releasing Mr Demirtaş and all other political prisoners. And will you also accept my challenge to put this on the table at the next meeting of the Council of Europe’s Committee of Ministers? Finally, I just want to quote my colleague Nacho Sánchez Amor: ‘That’s enough with the love letters.’ It is time for action. It is time for democracy.’

name: Barry Andrews (Renew).
text: – Mr President, I visited a pediatric hospital in Gaziantep in southern Turkey, and in the incubators were many tiny Syrian babies. I was amazed at how little social unrest flowed from the impact on public health services in that area, despite the large Syrian displaced population. When we criticise the Turkish Government, and we should, we should also remember the incredible welcome and, ultimately, vindication of human rights provided by the Turkish people to their Arabic-speaking neighbours in the decade since the Syrian uprising. I wonder if that welcome would be provided in every EU country. I know that in my own country, there are instances where reception centres for asylum seekers were burned down mysteriously before refuge could be provided to anybody seeking protection and fleeing a well-founded fear of persecution. I have no illusions about the Turkish Government. I will continue to campaign for İlhan Sami Çomak. He has been in jail since 1994. His case was found unsafe by the European Court of Human Rights in 2007 and he’s still in jail in 2021. It’s an outrage. But if we are to keep alive the dream of a common European future, we have to draw distinctions between the Turkish Government on the one hand, and the Turkish people on the other hand.

name: Bernhard Zimniok (ID).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Time and again, The issue of Erdogan is here in Parliament. Today, we are once again denouncing the blatant disregard for fundamental and human rights in Turkey, accusing the Turkish despots. Too often we have already done so and nothing has happened. But why wander into the distance, the bad is so close! There are also significant democratic deficits in Germany. On the one hand, there is a denunciation of the repression of the Kurdish HDP and others, and on the other hand, propaganda, the instrumentalization of constitutional protection and the forced-financed public media are being used against the AfD – the only opposition party in Germany. The goal: the exclusion and ultimately the annihilation of an annoying opponent in the political game. The ID Group is also being treated in the same way here in the European Parliament. Do we have a Vice-President, a committee chairman, who we are entitled to under the Rules of Procedure? No. At the beginning of the parliamentary term, all the political groups here in this House proudly proclaimed the cordon sanitaire instead of confronting the political debate. And why? Because we serve the European citizen and not the rest of the world on the basis of a confused ideology. I do not want to defend Erdogan. I would not be able to do anything further, as my many speeches on this subject show. But what is being done here in this House is pure hypocrisy, an openly demonstrated double standard. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, before you want to address democratic deficits worldwide, start here!

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is good that we are talking about Turkey, because it is a very important country, a very important partner of the European Union, also an extremely important NATO member, who in his region is certainly stabilising the situation in the context of what is happening, for example, in Iraq or Syria. Ten days ago, at a meeting with the ambassadors of the Member States of the Union, the Turkish Foreign Minister announced, let us call it, some liberalisation and stated that terrorism had been fought in Turkey for the last few years, but now it is time to focus on economic issues. What are the consequences? See. I think this is a step in the right direction.  I think it is necessary to talk to Turkey, to put forward our arguments, to look for what unites us, and, of course, to be admonished for those things that require it. I think we need dialogue first and foremost.

name: Isabel Wiseler-Lima (PPE).
text: Mr President, Turkey has the status of a candidate country for membership of the European Union. With this status, Turkey has made a commitment to respect freedom, democracy, the rule of law, human rights, pluralism, justice, as well as to be able to apply European law. The recall is necessary since the Turkish authorities do not even follow the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights to which they are subject.  A 2018 ruling by the Court, upheld in December 2020, obliges the Turkish authorities to immediately release Selahattin Demirtas. The Court found that Mr. Demirtas' detention was politically motivated and expressed concern about government interference in judicial cases.  If President Erdogan therefore wants to give a start to his recent commitments to carry out the reforms necessary to revive Turkey's accession process to the European Union, he could start by implementing the decisions of the European Court of Human Rights and have Mr Demirtas released. A minimal gesture that will have to be followed by many others so that we can begin to believe in promises never kept.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D).
text: Mr President, Selahattin Demirtas is Erdogan's hostage. He's been in prison for four years without trial. His arrest is the price of the fight for a peaceful resolution of the Kurdish issue, it is the price for a democratic Turkey that respects human rights. He is joined by other MPs, elected mayors and HDP officials; because the HDP is not only a pro-Kurdish party but a faction that rallies wider progressive forces around it, which do not tolerate the authoritarianism of Turkey's current president. That's why Erdogan hits them mercilessly. "I know what awaits me, but I cannot help but return to the side of my people," he told the Committee on Foreign Affairs the last time Demirtas visited Brussels before his arrest. Now it is our turn to stand by his side, not in words, but in deeds; that is why you will be judged at the March European Council. The European Court of Human Rights has shown the way forward.

name: Anna Bonfrisco (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative and Commissioner, I find it ironic that President Erdoğan is asking us to make the ontological choice to admit Turkey to the European Union. It is politically ironic, but tragic and painful for its victims, its citizens, its legitimate political opponents, who in a democracy have the right and public space to express themselves freely. Today's Turkey is a strategic challenge for Europe because the proposed model of political philosophy and political Islam is not democratic, it is not tolerant, it is not open to dialogue and it does not promote inalienable rights. The Turkish state political model that he offers us is therefore anti-European and it is grotesque that he should ask us to put an end to what he calls 'rhetoric against Turkey'. It is not rhetoric, it is the voice of human dignity trampled underfoot, today it is the voice of Selahattin Demirtas.

name: Andreas Schieder (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. We call for the immediate and immediate release of Selahattin Demirta', Figen Yüksekda', and many other opposition detainees: MPs, mayors, journalists, members of the opposition HDP and other parties. On 4 November 2016, Demirtaé was arrested along with eight other Members of Parliament in Turkey, along with eight other Members. The former MP and presidential candidate has been held innocently in Turkish prisons for four years. The European Court of Human Rights has on several occasions held that the arrest was contrary to human rights and that Demirta' and the others must be released immediately. Time and again, meps, including the opposition CHP, such as Kaftanciaolu and others, are repeatedly arrested and unlawfully convicted. Human rights are under pressure in Turkey. That is why we are calling for the release and for Turkey to finally recognise human rights standards and the European Court of Human Rights.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Union has repeatedly conveyed its serious concerns about the continued negative developments regarding the human rights situation in Turkey, along with specific recommendations in the Commission’s annual report on Turkey to urgently, and credibly, address all relevant shortcomings.  Meanwhile, the European Court of Human Rights issued decisions confirming our concerns and calling for immediate action. It concluded that Mr Demirtas’s extended detention violated the European Convention on Human Rights, including its Article 18. Moreover, the Turkish Constitutional Court stated that his right to freedom and security was violated during his trial and on remand beyond a reasonable period. What more can I say? Also, this House knows very well the situation of human rights defender, Osman Kavala, who has been held in pre—trial detention since November 2017, as well as the tragic case of Ebru Timtik. Moreover, decisions and actions taken by the Turkish authorities against mayors from opposition parties remain deeply concerning. Hundreds of local politicians, elected office holders and thousands of members of the People’s Democratic Party have been detained on terrorism-related charges, since the local elections in March 2019. Investigations were launched against others. Some even considered banning the HDP, which would clearly send a further very worrying signal.  We have always acknowledged that the Turkish Government has a legitimate right to fight terrorism. But it is also responsible for ensuring compliance with the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms, which are enshrined in Turkey’s Constitution and its international commitments. Concerns for the freedom of assembly in Turkey have also risen recently due to an amended regulation, which gives the Turkish police and intelligence access to military weaponry. We also cannot underestimate the threat that the recent law on preventing financing of proliferation of weapons of mass destruction presents to Turkish civil society, which already operates in a hostile environment.  The EU will continue to closely monitor the situation on the ground and to support Turkish civil society and human rights activists who face continuous pressure. We have made clear in our statements, most recently on 30 December, that, as a candidate country and long-standing member of the Council of Europe, Turkey urgently needs to make concrete and sustained progress in this and the respect of fundamental rights, which are a cornerstone of EU—Turkey relations. Progress on the cases of Mrs Demirtas and Kavala and other human rights cases is of the essence.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. – Turkey is now a huge prison with millions of people who are politically opposed to the neo-Ottoman regime, among them the political leader Demirtas. Under the Erdogan regime, there were 27,493 victims of torture and another 86 died. The biggest government project in recent years is to build €300m of prisons. The Chairman of the relevant Committee of the Council of Europe described Turkey as an authoritarian-dictatorial regime, stressing that there is no independent judiciary, but it is a government tool in its authoritarian politics. In addition, we are witnessing the Turkish expansionism in An. Mediterranean, Libya, Syria, Iraq and the Caucasus. If the above concerned another country, severe sanctions (trade, defence, etc.) would have already been imposed, but for Turkey certain Member State governments prevent them. Germany in particular is proceeding with the sale of state-of-the-art submarines to Turkey, to be used against European interests and member states in An. Mediterranean. I am addressing the people who understand the risks to European interests. The imposition of severe sanctions is a one-way street for Turkey to comply in practice with the European Court of Justice's rulings to end the repression and imprisonment of political dissidents. In the face of Demirtas, we honor the conscience of humanity fighting for freedom, justice and human rights. That's why I nominated him for the Sakharov Prize.

name: Presidente. –
text: The following is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the human rights situation in Vietnam, in particular the case of human rights journalists Pham Chi Dung, Nguyen Tuong Thuy and Le Huu Minh Tuan (2021/2507(RSP)).

name: Marco Campomenosi
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Commissioner Delli. The area of South-East Asia has strong geopolitical tensions, which our institutions should probably focus on. The tensions between China and Vietnam, the geopolitical settlement of countries such as Laos and Cambodia, however, do not justify what is happening within the Vietnamese regime, with arrests of journalists and bloggers, a role of social media which, as we have also seen in the Western world, is very problematic and perhaps in some cases, on what has happened in Vietnam, it is also complicit in a situation that obviously concerns freedom of expression. In the amendments tabled by my political group we also include references to the important problem of religious freedom, which also has a strong restriction on Christians, who are not a very small minority: they represent as much as 9 % of the inhabitants of the country. So it is clear that our role here is very much in difficulty. never applied.

name: Mick Wallace
text: author. – Mr President, today we have our third resolution this term in support of Western-backed anti-China protesters in Hong Kong, where police have killed no protestors yet. Why don’t we want to talk about Yemen, or Ethiopia? We have not had one resolution on the Saudi-UAE genocidal war being waged against the people of Yemen. The UN says the greatest humanitarian crisis in the world is taking place there. Millions are being intentionally starved to death. The UN says the number of people in Tigray, in northern Ethiopia, in need of life-saving assistance is at least 2.3 million, as a result of the war crimes of the unelected Abiy Ahmed. The changing of the guard in Ethiopia in 2018 was considered by the US as an opportunity for disrupting Chinese influence and now the US and the EU turn a blind Abiy’s war crimes, and all we want to talk about it in here are US-backed protesters in Hong Kong. Meanwhile, the EU and our friends are immune from criticism and when you have armed contracts with totalitarian regimes, who carry out terrible atrocities, you look the other way. I will take seriously the concern expressed in here for US-paid journalists imprisoned in Vietnam when you deal with the millions of starving and dying children in Yemen and demand they be free from Saudi-UAE aggression and free from the fear of the weapons of the US, Canadian, UK, French, German, Swedish Spanish and Belgian countries blowing them to pieces.

name: Saskia Bricmont
text: Author. Mr President, two years ago this Parliament adopted a resolution on the fate of political prisoners in Vietnam. Almost a year ago, this Parliament voted on the EU-Vietnam Trade and Investment Treaties. I remember that, in the face of skeptics like me, the proponents of the agreement said that it would change the human rights situation for the benefit of the population as a whole. While commitments have been made on labour law reform, the issue of human rights in Vietnam goes beyond the mere ratification of ILO conventions. Since then, repression has accelerated. Trade policy and human rights would therefore be two distinct elements. Not for Pham Chi Dung, president of the Association of Independent Journalists, who was arrested a few days after having spoken directly to us with a critical look at the process of ratifying the trade agreement. Sentenced to 15 years in prison for this, he is one of the three journalists for whom we now demand unconditional release along with Nguyen Tuong Thuy and Le Huu Minh Tuan, sentenced to 11 years in prison. The delegation of the European External Action Service in Hanoi continues to be concerned about the condemnation of hundreds of other pacifist activists, confirming a worrying reduction in the area of freedom of expression, assembly and association in the country. Our resolution therefore calls for the release of journalists and activists, the improvement of conditions of detention, especially in the context of the current pandemic, the adoption of a moratorium on the death penalty and the recall to Vietnam of its commitments to its own people, the European Union and the international community.

name: Adam Bielan
text: author. – Mr President, the EU has recently extended its hand to Vietnam with a free trade agreement (FTA) widening the horizons for companies both in Vietnam and in Europe, but we cannot continue to ignore the violation of fundamental rights currently happening in our economic partner. So today we call on the Vietnamese authorities to immediately release the three journalists recently incarcerated, as well as all journalists, bloggers and human rights defenders currently unfairly detained for having tried to express their opinions. Over recent years, the safety of journalists and whistle—blowers has taken a dramatic turn. Last year, while we were concluding our FTA, Reporters Without Borders ranked Vietnam 175th in the World Press Freedom Index. That is one place below Syria. This is why we urge the Vietnamese Government to also end the arbitrary censorship of independent news and media and delete the restrictions on online information sources. Through our new—found economic friendship, we probably have some tools to further bring this issue to the core of our exchanges with our partner country. Fundamental rights should definitely not be compromised with.

name: Marianne Vind
text: proposer. Mr President! Vietnam and the EU's relations are historically close and our cooperation has never been more important. Together, we lift a thousand people out of poverty, spread green technology and promote workers' rights. Separately we are weaker, together we are stronger.  That is why it is all the worse that the human rights situation in Vietnam is in retreat. Recently, several independent journalists and human rights defenders have been detained and convicted for their political activity. Dung, Thuy and Tuan have been sentenced to between 11 and 15 years in prison for so-called propaganda against the state. This is completely unheard of and unacceptable. Such acts are not only blatant repression of free and independent journalism, but also a clear attempt to deter citizens from criticising those in power.  Vietnam should release the wrongfully convicted immediately and revise its penal code and bring it into line with international standards. In the same vein, Vietnam should ratify ILO Conventions 87, 98 and 105, which it has, of course, committed itself to in the free trade agreement with the EUROPEAN Union. Cooperation between the EU and Vietnam is close, and it must remain so. But Vietnam must understand that our relationship is based on a common agreement on respect for human rights and freedoms. That is why I am pleased that today we are sending a strong signal with this resolution, which I look forward to voting through in parliament.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: author. – Mr President, Vietnam might be and is a rapidly emerging economy, but it also leads the track of human rights violations. We are observing an intensifying crackdown on basic civic and political rights in the country. Press freedom is squashed by state ownership of media sources. Censorship is thriving, as the new cybersecurity law enables control of the global social media networks. Any criticism of the government is a ticket to prison.  The three journalists whose case we are discussing today chose to carry out their professional duties despite any risks. One of them – Pham Chi Dung – reached out to us and warned about the false promises the Vietnamese Government makes in order to secure the trade deal with the European Union. We should have listened better! The European Union must use every available tool to assist and support these journalists along with hundreds of other civic activists imprisoned for simply doing their job while serving the public interest. Vietnam’s economic growth is dependent on the free trade agreements. Since the language of economic gains and losses might be the only language that the Vietnamese Government understands, we should consider reinstatement of tariffs for Vietnamese goods.

name: Seán Kelly
text: Údar. – A Uachtaráin, a Choimisinéir, Dia daoibh ó Bhaile Átha Cliath. Bhí áthas orm turas a thabhairt ar Vítneam nuair a bhí an idirbheartaíocht faoin gcomhréiteach saorthrádála ar siúl. Tír álainn is ea Vítneam le daoine iontacha flaithiúla míne, agus tá nasc tábhachtach trádála idir an tAontas Eorpach agus Vítneam againn anois. É sin ráite, ní féidir linn fanacht ciúin agus staid chearta daonna ag dul in olcas ann. Tá ar rialtas Vítneam cloí le gach píosa reachtaíochta, náisiúnta agus idirnáisiúnta, atá bainteach le cearta daonna a chosaint agus a chur chun cinn. Le mo chomh-Fheisirí, táimse ag lorg go scaoilfear leis an triúr iriseoirí atá ainmnithe sa Rún seo, láithreach agus gan choinníollacha. Cuireadh i bpríosún iad toisc gur bhaineadar leas as a saoirse cainte. Tá ar údaráis Vítneam, tá orthu, stop a chur le gach srian ar iriseoirí agus ar ghníomhaithe agus dlíodóirí atá ag obair ar son chearta an duine agus stop a chur freisin le cinsireacht. Ba cheart go mbeadh na daoine seo ábalta a bpoist a dhéanamh gan eagla a bheith orthu roimh na póilíní. Impím ar údaráis Vítneam beart a dhéanamh de réir ár dtuarascála anseo inniu agus an triúr iriseoirí, Pham Chi Dung, Nguyen Tuong Thuy agus Le Huu Minh Tuan, a ligean saor láithreach bonn. Agus impím ar an gCoimisinéir brú cuimsitheach a chur ar údaráis Vítneam chun é sin a dhéanamh. Bhí áthas orm, a Uachtaráin,  a bheith mar údar ar an tuarascáil thábhachtach seo. Go raibh míle maith agaibh ó Bhaile Átha Cliath.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, the degradation of human rights in the Socialist Republic of Vietnam is serious, public and notorious. Vietnam's only Communist Party hasn't called elections in years. There is no respect for human rights and there is no downside to eliminating any opponent, political activist or journalist who reports the lack of these rights. I will follow with interest what will be the vote of my communist colleagues in this House on this subject. You have already heard - and I say this to European journalists - to some European communist colleague to say that the murder and persecution of journalists in Vietnam do not have the same priority as other issues in the world. Vietnam has a privileged business relationship with the European Union. Not so countries with an established democracy, such as New Zealand, or others in development, such as Cambodia and other countries. I hope that in the next vote we will all come together clearly and without distinction from political groups in favour of denunciation and the changes that need to be operated in Vietnam, which is this country that has this trade relationship with the European Union.

name: Maria Arena
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, Commissioner, I will not speak to the authoritarian communist regime in Vietnam, because I do not believe in its desire to change in the area of human rights, but I will address European democracy. On 12 February 2020, this Parliament ratifies a trade and investment agreement between the European Union and Vietnam, despite all the reports that have been made since 2018, 2019, 2020 by Amnesty International or Human Rights Watch which denounced crimes and violations against the rights of Vietnamese people.  However, the rapporteur of the Committee on International Trade in charge of this dossier, Mr Bourgeois, had been there in 2018 when he was Belgian minister. He must have known. Yet he did not address the issue of human rights. And the same rapporteur who found himself in this Parliament was telling us that if we recorded serious and systemic human rights violations, we would suspend trade preferences. Well, I am speaking to Mr Bourgeois, I am speaking to the Commission, these serious violations exist, they existed and they will continue to exist. And so I ask that there be a suspension of preferential agreements with Vietnam.

name: Karin Karlsbro
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, the free trade agreement with Vietnam is the most ambitious that EU’s ever negotiated with a developing country.  When we adopted it, we expected it to be not only an economic win-win for both parties, but also an opportunity to advance sustainable trade, to advance democracy and human rights. Initially, we did see some positive results, especially on human rights. But the human rights situation is unacceptable, and the development so far has been very disappointing. We ask now for the immediate release of the journalists and political prisoners. Now is the time to step up our pressure, and use the agreement as the platform for supporters and civil society as we promised. When we adopted the trade agreement we also called upon the Commission and the European External Action Service to swiftly carry out a comprehensive human-rights impact assessment of the agreement. Today we repeat that call.

name: Patryk Jaki
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Communism always ends as we see it at the moment by implementing the policies of the communist authorities in Vietnam. Since it is an ideology that defies human rights, common sense and logic, it must sooner or later stiuce freedom of expression because it does not tolerate free debate. That is why it is good that today we have this motion for a resolution, because what has happened, what has been going on there for a long time, but what has happened recently, i.e. the sentence of between eleven and fifteen years in prison for criticising communist power, is unacceptable. And it is good for the EU institutions to take very firm action against Vietnam. This type of activity cannot be accepted. But what's really disturbing is that big tech companies like Facebook and Google are also involved in censorship. Here, too, the European Parliament and the European institutions should take a hard line, because these companies also make a great deal of money within the European Union and cannot be allowed to participate in censorship.

name: Isabel Wiseler-Lima (PPE).
text: Mr President, a year ago the European Parliament approved free trade and investment protection agreements with Vietnam. However, there remained strong concerns about the communist regime's compliance with the commitments these agreements implied in respect of human rights and respect for international labour law. Therefore, Commissioner, we have matched these agreements with the call for an independent human rights monitoring mechanism and an independent complaint mechanism so that citizens have effective access to recourse. These mechanisms have not yet been implemented. We urge the Commission and the Vietnamese authorities to have them put in place. Similarly, we regret that the internal advisory groups included in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement are still not operational. It is unacceptable that Vietnam does not respect an integral part of the agreements without having consequences. We feel particularly like an affront that Pham Chi Dung has been imprisoned and is still imprisoned for contacting MEPs in the context of free trade and investment agreements. The European Parliament calls on the Vietnamese authorities to release him and other journalists and human rights defenders so unjustly imprisoned.

name: Pascal Durand (Renew).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I, too, like my excellent colleague Maria Arena, do not want to address the totalitarian Dictatorship of Vietnam. I want to go to the Commission, to the treaty watchdog. And what do the treaties tell us? Sometimes it's good to go back to the text. Article 21 of the Treaty on the European Union is very clear. The Union's action on the international stage is based on the principles that presided over its creation, which it aims to promote in the rest of the world: democracy, the rule of law, universality and the indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms. He adds: the EU is working to develop relations and build partnerships with third countries that share the principles covered in the first paragraph. So, Commissioner, make sure that these principles are applied and respected or else, if not, for the sake of intellectual honesty, let us add a paragraph to the Treaty and say that these principles do not apply when the markets, profits and financial interests of European companies are at stake.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, we repeatedly expressed to Vietnam our concerns over limitations to freedom of expression, both online and offline, as reflected in increasing cases of intimidation, arrest, detention and sentencing of journalists and human rights defenders who express their opinions. The space for dissenting voices is shrinking and the sentences of Mr Pham Chi Dung, Mr Nguyen Tuong Thuy and Mr Le Huu Minh Tuan show a deterioration of the civil and political rights situation.  The EU has called on the authorities to respect fundamental rights enshrined in their constitution and in international conventions to which they are party, most recently in a statement issued by the spokesperson for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on 6 January. At the same time, we aim to constructively engage the authorities to ensure alignment with international standards, by offering assistance in implementing the recommendations which Vietnam accepted under its latest Universal Periodic Review.  Political and civil rights and rule of law are regularly raised at the human rights dialogue with Vietnam. During the last session in February 2020 the EU reiterated its request for all Vietnamese citizens detained for exercising their freedom of opinion and expression to be released. The EU also referred to a number of individual cases and stressed that the negative trend of limiting freedom of expression must be reversed, especially when Vietnam and the EU are engaged in closer partnership. Additionally, the EU has supported projects by, and with, civil society organisations, enhancing citizens’ engagement in policy advocacy and promoting human rights.  Reform and modernisation allowed Vietnam to make continuous progress in economic and social rights, steadily opening up to international standards. The EU has supported Vietnam in moving from limited regional economic integration to broader international integration, including international standards. This includes ongoing reforms in the area of labour rights.  Against this background, we will continue to reiterate at every occasion that citizens’ opinions expressed peacefully are a critical part of prosperous societies and are essential for sustainable development. We will continue to work together with Vietnam to achieve a more inclusive society and be very clear about our expectations.
